name: Eucharistic Miracle of Lanciano

location.address: Church of St. Francis (San Francesco), Lanciano

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Flesh; Wine into Blood)
description: During Mass, the consecrated Host became human Flesh and the wine became human Blood before the congregation.
narrative: Around the year 750 A.D., at the Church of St. Francis in Lanciano, a Basilian monk who doubted the Real Presence was celebrating Mass when, at the words of consecration, the Host visibly turned into Flesh and the wine into Blood. The transformation was witnessed by those present. The Flesh has remained intact through the centuries, and the Blood separated into five unequal clots that together weigh the same as each clot individually—an unexplained phenomenon. The relics were preserved and venerated, drawing pilgrims for generations. In the modern era, ecclesiastical authorities authorized scientific investigations to examine the relics while maintaining their devotional custody.
scientificEvidence: Extensive studies (notably in 1970–1971 and later reviews) identified the Flesh as human myocardial tissue (heart muscle) and the Blood as human blood type AB, with proteins and mineral composition consistent with fresh human blood; no preservatives were found, and the tissue showed characteristics of a living heart at the time of transformation.
significance: One of the most renowned and scientifically studied Eucharistic miracles, Lanciano has profoundly influenced Eucharistic devotion worldwide and serves as a cornerstone testimony to the Catholic doctrine of the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Buenos Aires

location.address: Parish of Santa María, Buenos Aires

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into cardiac tissue)
description: A consecrated Host transformed into living human heart tissue and blood following proper Eucharistic handling.
narrative: Between 1992 and 1996, three Eucharistic miracles occurred at the parish of Santa María in Buenos Aires...
scientificEvidence: Forensic pathology, histology, and DNA testing identified the substance as living human cardiac muscle tissue...
significance: The miracle strongly supports Catholic teaching on the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist and was overseen by the future Pope Francis...

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Tumaco

location.address: Tumaco Island, Pacific Coast

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Blessed Sacrament halting natural disaster)
description: A tsunami caused by a powerful earthquake halted after a priest raised the Blessed Sacrament on the shore of Tumaco.
narrative: On January 31, 1906, a massive undersea earthquake off the Pacific coast triggered a devastating tsunami that struck many coastal regions. As the waters surged toward the small island of Tumaco, Fr. Gerardo Larrondo was urged by the terrified villagers to bring the Blessed Sacrament. Carrying the monstrance, he processed to the beach with the faithful as the enormous wave advanced inland. Standing before the sea, Fr. Larrondo raised the Blessed Sacrament and traced the sign of the cross. At that moment, the wave suddenly stopped, receded, and the waters returned to their normal level. Tumaco was spared total destruction, and the event was widely regarded as a miraculous intervention attributed to the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.
scientificEvidence: Eyewitness testimony from clergy and townspeople documented the sudden and unexplained retreat of the tsunami despite ongoing seismic activity affecting surrounding regions.
significance: The miracle reinforced Catholic belief in the power of the Eucharist and became known internationally, with Fr. Larrondo receiving letters from around the world requesting prayers.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Ludbreg

location.address: Chapel of the Batthyány Castle, Ludbreg

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Wine transformed into Blood)
description: During Mass, consecrated wine visibly transformed into Blood after a priest doubted the Real Presence.
narrative: In 1411, while celebrating Mass in the chapel of the Batthyány Castle in Ludbreg, a priest experienced doubt about the doctrine of transubstantiation. Immediately after the consecration, the wine in the chalice turned into visible Blood. Unsure how to proceed, the priest sealed the relic within the altar. News of the miracle soon spread, and pilgrims began arriving in Ludbreg. A Church commission later investigated the event, and in 1513 Pope Leo X approved public veneration of the Precious Blood, which he personally carried in procession through Rome. The relic has remained preserved through the centuries and is still venerated today. Each year, the town celebrates a week-long devotion known as “Sveta Nedjelja” (Holy Sunday) in remembrance of the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The Blood relic has remained preserved and intact for centuries and was formally examined and approved for veneration by ecclesiastical authorities.
significance: The miracle strongly affirmed belief in the Real Presence and received papal approval, becoming one of the most enduring and venerated Eucharistic miracles in Europe.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Chirattakonam

location.address: St. Mary’s Malankara Catholic Church, Chirattakonam, Kerala

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Image of Christ appeared on Host)
description: The face of Christ visibly appeared on a consecrated Host during Mass.
narrative: On April 28, 2001, during Mass at St. Mary’s Malankara Catholic Church in Chirattakonam, Fr. Thomas Pathickal noticed a mysterious spot forming on a consecrated Host shortly after the consecration. As Mass continued, the spot gradually developed into a clear image resembling the face of Jesus Christ. The Host was reverently set aside and later examined by Church authorities. The faithful who viewed the Host reported deep spiritual impact. After careful investigation, the Syro-Malankara Catholic Church officially recognized the event as a Eucharistic miracle and authorized public veneration of the Host.
scientificEvidence: The miracle involves a visible image rather than physical transformation; ecclesiastical investigation focused on authenticity, continuity of the image, and theological consistency rather than laboratory testing.
significance: This miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in India and affirmed Catholic belief in the Real Presence, particularly within the Syro-Malankara Catholic Church.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Morne-Rouge

location.address: Parish Church of Morne-Rouge, Martinique

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of Christ and protection from natural disaster)
description: An apparition of Jesus and His Sacred Heart appeared in the Host as the village was spared from a volcanic eruption.
narrative: On May 8, 1902, the volcano Mount Pelée erupted violently, instantly destroying the nearby city of Saint-Pierre. That same day, the village of Morne-Rouge, located between Saint-Pierre and the volcano, was mysteriously spared. During Eucharistic adoration, many faithful witnessed an apparition of Jesus Christ and His Sacred Heart appearing in the consecrated Host exposed in the monstrance. In fear and repentance, the villagers rushed to confession, received Holy Communion, and remained in prayer. The Blessed Sacrament was later reposed, and the apparition ceased. Morne-Rouge was preserved from destruction during this eruption, though a later eruption on August 30, 1902 eventually destroyed the village, reinforcing the belief that its earlier salvation was a moment of divine mercy.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is based on multiple eyewitness testimonies describing the visible apparition of Christ in the Eucharist and the unexplained preservation of the village during the initial volcanic eruption.
significance: The event emphasized Eucharistic faith, repentance, and divine mercy, becoming a powerful testimony to the Real Presence and God’s intervention during moments of catastrophe.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Saint-André de la Réunion

location.address: Parish Church of Saint-André, La Réunion

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Image of Christ appeared on Host)
description: The face of Jesus appeared on the consecrated Host and was witnessed for many hours by large crowds.
narrative: On January 26, 1902, at the parish church of Saint-André on the island of La Réunion, Abbot Henry Lacombe was celebrating Mass when, during Eucharistic adoration, the face of Jesus appeared on the consecrated Host exposed in the monstrance. The apparition was clearly visible and lasted for several hours. Thousands of faithful came to witness the phenomenon, including journalists and clergy. The image changed over time, at moments showing Christ crowned with thorns and later appearing as a crucifix. After Eucharistic Benediction and the chanting of the Tantum Ergo, the vision disappeared. Abbot Lacombe later testified publicly about the miracle during the Eucharistic Congress of Angoulême in 1904 and to groups of priests during retreats in France.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by extensive eyewitness testimony from clergy, faithful, and journalists who observed the apparition over several hours; the Church evaluated the credibility of witnesses and consistency of accounts.
significance: The miracle greatly strengthened Eucharistic devotion and belief in the Real Presence, drawing thousands to adoration and becoming widely known beyond the island of La Réunion.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Tixtla

location.address: Parish of Saint Mary of the Assumption, Diocese of Chilpancingo–Chilapa

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host bleeding; cardiac tissue identified)
description: A consecrated Host began to exude blood that was later identified as living human cardiac tissue.
narrative: On October 21, 2006, during a spiritual retreat in Tixtla within the Diocese of Chilpancingo–Chilapa, a consecrated Host began to exude a reddish substance while being handled during Eucharistic adoration. The phenomenon continued over time. Ecclesiastical authorities initiated a thorough investigation, and between 2009 and 2012 multiple independent scientific analyses were conducted. The results were presented publicly in 2013 and confirmed that the substance originated from within the Host. On October 12, 2013, Bishop Alejo Zavala Castro formally recognized the supernatural character of the events, declaring the bleeding Host of Tixtla a divine sign affirming the Real Presence of Jesus Christ in the Eucharist.
scientificEvidence: Laboratory analyses identified the substance as human blood of type AB containing hemoglobin, DNA, intact white and red blood cells, active macrophages, and living cardiac muscle tissue (myocardium). Histopathological and immunohistochemical studies confirmed the tissue was heart muscle with signs of vitality, including mesenchymal cells and recovery trades, and demonstrated that the blood flowed from the interior of the Host rather than being applied externally.
significance: The miracle provides one of the most extensively documented modern Eucharistic miracles, offering strong theological and scientific support for Catholic belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Eten

location.address: Church of Santa María Magdalena, Eten

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of the Child Jesus in the Host)
description: The Child Jesus appeared in a consecrated Host exposed for public adoration.
narrative: On June 2, 1649, during the solemn exposition of the Blessed Sacrament in honor of Corpus Christi at the port town of Eten, Peru, the Franciscan friar Jerome de Silva Manrique exposed the Eucharist in the monstrance. At the end of the service, a radiant image of the Child Jesus appeared in the Host, with light shining from His face and shoulders. The faithful present witnessed the apparition. A second apparition occurred weeks later on July 22, during celebrations for St. Mary Magdalene, in which the Divine Child again appeared in the Host, accompanied by three small white hearts united together, symbolizing the Holy Trinity. The apparitions lasted about fifteen minutes and were carefully documented by ecclesiastical authorities. Since that time, devotion to the Divine Child of Eten has continued, drawing pilgrims annually.
scientificEvidence: The miracle consists of visible apparitions witnessed by clergy and the faithful; Church authorities evaluated testimonies and preserved the accounts without recourse to laboratory analysis.
significance: The miracle fostered lasting devotion to the Divine Child of Eten and reinforced belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist throughout Peru and beyond.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Santarém

location.address: Church of St. Stephen (Igreja de Santo Estêvão), Santarém

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into bleeding Flesh and Blood)
description: A consecrated Host began to bleed and transformed into Flesh and Blood after being stolen and hidden.
narrative: According to a document commissioned by King Alfonso IV in 1346, on February 16, 1266, a woman in Santarém, distressed by jealousy toward her husband, sought help from a sorceress who instructed her to steal a consecrated Host for a love potion. After receiving Communion, she removed the Host and hid it in a linen cloth, which immediately became stained with Blood. At home, the Host began to gush Blood, and during the night brilliant rays of light illuminated the room from a drawer where it was kept. The husband, witnessing the phenomenon, confronted his wife, who confessed the sacrilege. The following day, the Host was returned in solemn procession to the Church of St. Stephen, where it continued to bleed for three days. In 1340, when the priest opened the tabernacle, the beeswax reliquary containing the Host was found broken, replaced by a crystal vessel containing Blood mixed with wax. The relic has been preserved and venerated ever since, with renewed emissions of Blood and visions of Christ reported over the centuries.
scientificEvidence: Numerous canonical investigations and studies were carried out over the centuries; the relics of Flesh and Blood have remained preserved and are still venerated today.
significance: Considered one of the most important Eucharistic miracles alongside Lanciano, the miracle received papal recognition and indulgences and has been a major center of Eucharistic devotion for centuries.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Ettiswil

location.address: Shrine of the Eucharistic Miracle, Ettiswil

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host miraculously divided and surrounded by light)
description: A stolen Host was found divided into seven pieces arranged like a flower and surrounded by a vivid light.
narrative: On May 23, 1447, a consecrated Host was stolen from the parish church of Ettiswil by Anna Vögtli. Unable to carry it further, she discarded it near a fence among nettles. The Host was later discovered by Margaret Schulmeister, a swineherd, who observed that her animals refused to approach the spot. With witnesses present, the Host was seen divided into seven pieces arranged like a radiant flower and surrounded by intense light. When the parish priest arrived to recover the Host, six pieces were lifted, but the central piece adhered firmly to the ground before everyone’s eyes. Interpreting this as a divine sign, it was decided to build a chapel on that very spot. The six pieces were taken to the church and became objects of great veneration. Numerous miracles were reported, and the chapel and altar were consecrated on December 28, 1448.
scientificEvidence: The event is documented in the official 'Protocol of Justice' compiled on July 16, 1447, containing sworn testimonies and detailed descriptions of the phenomenon.
significance: The miracle became a major center of pilgrimage in Switzerland, received papal indulgences, and strengthened devotion to the Real Presence in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Betania

location.address: Shrine of Betania, Cúa; relic preserved in Los Teques

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host with cardiac-like pulsation)
description: During Mass, a consecrated Host began to bleed and was later observed pulsating like a heart.
narrative: On December 8, 1991, while celebrating Mass in the chapel of the Shrine of Betania in Cúa, Father Otty Ossa Aristizábal noticed that the consecrated Host was bleeding during the consecration. The Host was reverently preserved and later transferred to the city of Los Teques, where it is kept at the convent of the Augustinian Recollect Nuns of the Sacred Heart of Jesus for perpetual adoration. Over time, numerous prodigious events were associated with the Host. One notable event involved a young American pilgrim who filmed the Host visibly pulsating like a heart while it was exposed for adoration. The phenomenon drew widespread attention and devotion from pilgrims in Venezuela and abroad.
scientificEvidence: Ecclesiastical investigations reported that the blood was of human origin and of blood type AB, consistent with findings in other recognized Eucharistic miracles; observations noted that the blood flowed from a specific area of the Host without staining the remainder.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in Venezuela, becoming a major pilgrimage site and reinforcing belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Fiecht

location.address: Monastery of St. Georgenberg-Fiecht, Inn Valley

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Wine transformed into Blood)
description: During Mass, the consecrated wine changed into Blood and overflowed the chalice.
narrative: In 1310, at the monastery of St. Georgenberg-Fiecht in the Inn Valley, a priest was troubled by doubts concerning the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. Immediately after the consecration, the wine in the chalice changed into visible Blood, which began to boil and overflow. The abbot, monks, and numerous faithful present witnessed the phenomenon and reverently consumed part of the Precious Blood, preserving the remainder in the tabernacle. News of the miracle spread quickly, drawing pilgrims to the monastery. After ecclesiastical investigation, the miracle was declared authentic, and devotion to the Precious Blood flourished throughout the region. Centuries later, chronicles attest that the Blood remained fresh and intact, and it is preserved to this day in a reliquary at the monastery.
scientificEvidence: Historical chronicles and ecclesiastical investigations documented the transformation and long-term preservation of the Precious Blood, which was reported to remain fresh centuries after the event.
significance: The miracle strengthened belief in the Real Presence, became a major center of pilgrimage in Tyrol, and fostered enduring devotion to the Precious Blood of Christ.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Seefeld

location.address: Church of St. Oswald, Seefeld in Tyrol

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host and supernatural intervention)
description: A consecrated Host began to bleed after a nobleman attempted to receive an oversized Host during Mass.
narrative: In 1384, during the Holy Thursday Mass in Seefeld, Oswald Milser, Lord of Schlosberg, demanded to receive Communion with the large Host reserved for the celebrant priest. As he approached the altar to receive it, the pavement beneath him began to tremble and cracked open, causing him to sink into the floor while grasping the altar. The priest immediately withdrew the Host from Milser’s mouth, at which point the trembling ceased and living blood began to drip from the Host. Numerous witnesses observed the miracle, and news quickly spread throughout the region. The blood-stained Host was preserved and exposed for veneration in the Church of St. Oswald, which became a major pilgrimage destination. Emperor Maximilian I himself showed great devotion to the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by extensive eyewitness testimony recorded by ecclesiastical authorities and preserved through centuries of devotion and pilgrimage.
significance: The miracle reinforced reverence for the Eucharist, corrected abuses motivated by pride, and strengthened belief in the Real Presence throughout Austria and beyond.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Weiten-Raxendorf

location.address: Parish Church of Weiten; Chapel at the site of the miracle

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host divided yet united by bleeding flesh)
description: A stolen Host was found glowing, divided into two pieces yet united by threads of bleeding flesh.
narrative: In 1411, during a period of frequent Host thefts in Austria, a thief broke into the sacristy of the parish church in Weiten and stole a consecrated Host, hiding it in his glove. While traveling through the valley toward Spitz, his horse suddenly stopped and could not be moved. Without being noticed, the Host fell from the glove to the ground. Several days later, a pious woman named Mrs. Scheck passed by the spot and saw the Host shining with a brilliant light. Upon lifting it, she discovered that it was divided into two parts but still united by threads of bleeding flesh. Deeply moved, she built a small chapel at her own expense on the site. As news spread, pilgrims began to arrive in great numbers, and a larger church was later constructed to accommodate the growing devotion to the miraculous relic.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by detailed historical accounts and eyewitness testimony describing the luminous Host and its physical condition.
significance: The event strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, led to the establishment of a major pilgrimage site, and reinforced belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bois-Seigneur-Isaac

location.address: Monastery of Bois-Seigneur-Isaac, Chapel of the Holy Blood

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host staining the corporal)
description: A consecrated Host bled during Mass and stained the corporal, which has been preserved for veneration.
narrative: In 1405, during Mass at Bois-Seigneur-Isaac, the consecrated Host adhered to the corporal and began to bleed, staining it with Blood. The phenomenon continued over several days, with the Blood spreading across the cloth. Ecclesiastical authorities opened a formal investigation, collecting testimonies from witnesses. On May 3, 1413, the Bishop of Cambrai, Pierre d’Ailly, authorized public devotion to the Holy Relic and established a solemn procession, first held in 1414. On January 13, 1424, Pope Martin V approved the construction of the monastery. The blood-stained corporal is still preserved and exposed for veneration in the Chapel of the Holy Blood, and the site remains a destination for pilgrims.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through canonical investigations and eyewitness testimony; the blood-stained corporal has been preserved over centuries and remains intact.
significance: The miracle received episcopal and papal approval, led to the foundation of a monastery, and became a lasting center of Eucharistic devotion in Belgium.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bruges (Most Precious Blood of Jesus)

location.address: Basilica of the Holy Blood (Basiliek van het Heilig Bloed), Bruges

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Relic of the Precious Blood of Christ)
description: A relic venerated as the Most Precious Blood of Jesus has been preserved and publicly honored in Bruges since the 13th century.
narrative: The oldest documents concerning the Holy Blood of Bruges date back to 1256. According to historical tradition, the relic of the Precious Blood of Christ was preserved among the Passion relics in Constantinople and came into the possession of Baldwin IX, Count of Flanders, after the city was conquered during the Fourth Crusade. The relic was later sent to Bruges, Baldwin’s homeland. While an older tradition attributed its arrival to Count Diederik van den Elzas during the Second Crusade, modern investigations indicate the relic likely arrived around 1250 from Constantinople. The Holy Blood has since been preserved in a crystal vial dated to the 11th century and housed in the Basilica of the Holy Blood. Its veneration gave rise to the famous annual Procession of the Holy Blood, held on the Feast of the Ascension, during which the citizens of Bruges reenact biblical scenes and the arrival of the relic.
scientificEvidence: Analyses of the crystal vial date it to the 11th century and confirm its origin near Constantinople; the relic itself has been preserved intact and continuously venerated.
significance: The Holy Blood of Bruges is one of the most revered Eucharistic-related relics in Europe and has inspired centuries of devotion, pilgrimage, and one of the most renowned religious processions in the Catholic world.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Brussels

location.address: Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula, Brussels

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Hosts after desecration)
description: Consecrated Hosts bled after being slashed with knives during a desecration.
narrative: In 1370, following the theft of consecrated Hosts in Brussels, desecrators gathered on Good Friday and slashed the Hosts with knives as an act of rebellion against the Catholic faith. Immediately, living blood flowed from the wounded Hosts. Terrified, the perpetrators entrusted the Hosts to a Catholic merchant, who revealed the events to the curate of the Church of Notre Dame. The Hosts were solemnly taken in procession to the Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula. The Duke of Brabant condemned the desecrators, and the miraculous Hosts became objects of public veneration. Over the centuries, the miracle was commemorated through reliquaries, tapestries, and especially a series of stained-glass windows installed between 1436 and 1870, many donated by Belgian royalty and noble families.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through contemporaneous accounts, canonical investigations, and enduring artistic testimonies including reliquaries and stained-glass cycles depicting the events.
significance: The miracle became a major religious and cultural symbol for Brussels and Belgium, strengthening Eucharistic devotion and leaving a lasting artistic and devotional legacy.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Herentals

location.address: Cathedral of St. Waldetrudis (Sint-Waldetrudiskerk), Herentals; field site of De Hegge shrine

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Recovered Hosts found intact and radiant)
description: Previously stolen Hosts were found intact after days in the open, arranged in the form of a cross and surrounded by light.
narrative: In 1412, several consecrated Hosts stolen from Herentals were later discovered after eight days in a field near a rabbit burrow. Despite exposure to rain and weather, the Hosts were found perfectly intact, glowing with a brilliant light and arranged in the shape of a cross. The discovery moved the faithful deeply. Annual commemorations developed, including processions featuring paintings depicting the miracle and a commemorative Mass celebrated at the site known as De Hegge, where a small shrine was built. The relics and artistic testimonies are preserved in Herentals, especially at the Cathedral of St. Waldetrudis.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by historical records and eyewitness testimony noting the intact condition of the Hosts after prolonged exposure and their radiant appearance.
significance: The event strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, led to enduring public commemorations, and became an important local pilgrimage tradition in Belgium.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Herkenrode–Hasselt

location.address: Church of St. Quintinus (Sint-Quintinuskathedraal), Hasselt; former Abbey of Herkenrode

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host with apparition of Christ)
description: A consecrated Host became stained with blood and later revealed the face of Christ crowned with thorns.
narrative: On July 25, 1317, the pastor of Viversel carried a consecrated Host to a sick parishioner. While the priest was hearing confession, a family member briefly handled the pyx containing the Host. When the priest later opened the pyx, he found the Host stained with blood and adhered to the linen. Alarmed, he sought counsel and was directed to bring the Host to the Abbey of Herkenrode. On August 1, 1317, along the journey extraordinary signs were reported, and upon arrival at the Benedictine monastery, the Host was shown to many witnesses. At that moment, the face of Christ crowned with thorns appeared on the Host, attested by numerous observers. The relic was placed in a reliquary and exposed for public veneration, and it was credited on several occasions with protecting the monastery from fire. In 1804, the relic was transferred to the Church of St. Quintinus in Hasselt, where it remains venerated today.
scientificEvidence: Across the centuries, multiple ecclesiastical examinations were conducted, including investigations in the 18th century by the Apostolic Nuncio Carafa, the Bishop of Liège, and later by the Archbishop of Malines, confirming the extraordinary preservation of the Host and the blood stains.
significance: The miracle became a major focus of Eucharistic devotion in the region, inspired enduring public veneration and processions, and remains one of Belgium’s most important medieval Eucharistic miracles.

name: Institution of the Feast of Corpus Christi

location.address: Sanctuary of Saint Juliana of Cornillon, Liège

type: Eucharistic Event (Vision leading to universal feast)
description: Mystical visions received by Saint Juliana of Cornillon led to the establishment of the Feast of Corpus Christi.
narrative: In the early 13th century, Blessed Juliana of Cornillon, an Augustinian nun near Liège, experienced repeated visions of a full moon marked by a dark spot. Through divine revelation, she understood the moon to represent the life of the Church and the dark spot the absence of a feast dedicated solely to honoring the Holy Eucharist. She reported these visions to Church authorities, including Jacques Panteléon, Archdeacon of Liège. In 1246, Bishop Robert of Thourotte instituted a diocesan feast in honor of the Blessed Sacrament, celebrated for the first time in 1249. In 1264, Jacques Panteléon—now Pope Urban IV—extended the Feast of Corpus Christi to the entire Catholic Church through the papal bull *Transiturus de hoc mundo* and commissioned Saint Thomas Aquinas to compose the liturgical texts for the feast.
scientificEvidence: The event is based on documented mystical visions and authoritative ecclesiastical actions rather than physical or laboratory evidence.
significance: The visions at Liège gave rise to the universal Feast of Corpus Christi, one of the most important liturgical celebrations affirming the doctrine of the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Middleburg–Lovanio

location.address: St. Peter’s Church, Middleburg; relic later preserved in Louvain (Leuven)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into bleeding Flesh)
description: During Holy Communion, the consecrated Host changed into bleeding Flesh in the priest’s mouth.
narrative: In 1374, at St. Peter’s Church in Middleburg, a woman known for her deep piety invited her household to prepare spiritually for Easter through penance and confession. One servant, Jan, who had not been to confession for many years and lived a dissolute life, reluctantly attended Mass and approached Holy Communion. As soon as he received the consecrated Host on his tongue, it transformed into bleeding Flesh. A particle fell from his mouth, and blood dripped onto the altar cloth. The priest immediately recognized the miracle. Jan repented sincerely, confessed his sins, and amended his life, remaining devoted to the Eucharist until his death. After thorough investigation, the Archbishop approved the cult of the miracle. A portion of the Precious Relic was later given as a gift to Jean de Gheest, confessor of the Archbishop, and preserved in Louvain by the Augustinian Fathers, while another portion remained in St. Peter’s Church in Middleburg.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by extensive historical documentation, eyewitness testimony, and a monograph written in 1905 by historian Joseph Wils of the University of Louvain, citing contemporary documents and sworn accounts.
significance: The miracle reinforced belief in the Real Presence, inspired profound repentance and conversion, and received formal ecclesiastical approval, becoming a lasting focus of Eucharistic devotion in Belgium.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of St. Mary of Egypt

location.address: Jordan River crossing; Desert east of the Jordan

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous reception of Holy Communion)
description: St. Mary of Egypt miraculously crossed the Jordan River to receive Holy Communion after decades of desert penance.
narrative: This Eucharistic miracle is connected to the life of St. Mary of Egypt, who lived as a hermit in the desert for forty-seven years in repentance and prayer. According to the account written by Bishop Sophronius of Jerusalem in the 7th century, St. Mary met the monk Zosimus and asked him to bring her Holy Communion the following year. When Zosimus returned, he saw St. Mary cross the Jordan River by walking on the water to reach him. After receiving Confession and Holy Communion from Zosimus, she asked him to return the next year. When he did, he found her body lying peacefully in the desert. A lion helped Zosimus dig her grave, and she was buried as a saintly witness to repentance, holiness, and reverence for the Eucharist.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is based on early hagiographical testimony recorded by Bishop Sophronius of Jerusalem, preserved consistently in Eastern and Western Christian tradition.
significance: The event highlights the centrality of the Eucharist in Christian life, demonstrating repentance, sanctity, and the supernatural power granted through reverence for Holy Communion.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Scete

location.address: Desert of Scete (Wadi El Natrun), monastic region of the Desert Fathers

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Vision of the Infant Jesus at Consecration)
description: During the Eucharistic consecration, the Infant Jesus appeared on the bread and Blood flowed into the chalice.
narrative: The account of this Eucharistic miracle dates back to the early centuries of Christianity and is preserved in the sayings of the Fathers of the Desert who lived in Scete after the example of St. Anthony the Abbot. A monk expressed doubts about the Real Presence of Jesus Christ in the bread and wine consecrated at Mass, claiming they were only symbols. After the consecration, the Infant Jesus was visibly seen resting on the bread, and three companion monks witnessed the same apparition. According to another ancient account, an angel appeared holding a sword and pierced the Child, causing Blood to flow into the chalice. When the doubting monk approached Communion, the angel gave him flesh and blood instead of bread and wine. Terrified, the monk professed his faith in the Real Presence, after which the flesh returned to the form of bread, and he received Communion reverently. The miracle deeply strengthened Eucharistic faith among the Desert Fathers.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is preserved through early monastic writings and oral tradition recorded in the apophthegmata of the Desert Fathers rather than scientific or laboratory analysis.
significance: One of the earliest recorded Eucharistic miracles, it powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence among the early monastic communities and influenced Christian Eucharistic theology.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Avignon

location.address: Church of the Holy Cross (Chapelle des Pénitents Gris), Avignon

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Blessed Sacrament preserved during flood)
description: During a major flood, the waters parted inside the church, leaving a dry path to the altar where the Blessed Sacrament remained unharmed.
narrative: On November 30, 1433, after several days of heavy rain caused the Sorgue and Rhône rivers to overflow, the city of Avignon was submerged by floodwaters. A small church of the Gray Penitents of the Franciscan Order had been left with the Blessed Sacrament exposed for perpetual adoration. Fearing the Host had been swept away, the head of the Order and another friar reached the church by boat. Upon entering, they witnessed a miracle: although water stood about four feet high around the church, the waters inside were divided to the right and left, leaving a perfectly dry pathway from the entrance to the altar. The Sacred Host was completely unscathed. The scene recalled the parting of the Red Sea in the time of Moses. Many witnesses, including civic and religious authorities, came to verify the event, praising God. The miracle has been commemorated annually ever since on November 30 at the Chapelle des Pénitents Gris, with chants from the Canticle of Moses.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by extensive eyewitness testimony describing the unexplained division of floodwaters and the preservation of a dry pathway to the altar.
significance: The miracle powerfully reinforced Eucharistic faith in Avignon, then considered a center of Christendom, and remains one of the city’s most celebrated signs of devotion to the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Blanot

location.address: Parish Church of Blanot, Diocese of Autun

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Blood staining the communion cloth)
description: During Communion, a Host fell onto a cloth and transformed into Blood, leaving a stain the size of the Host.
narrative: The Eucharistic Miracle of Blanot occurred during the Easter Mass of 1331. While administering Holy Communion, a consecrated Host fell onto a cloth held beneath the communicant’s mouth. When the priest attempted to pick up the Host, it was no longer possible, as it had transformed into Blood, leaving a clearly defined stain—equal in size and shape to the Host—on the cloth. The event was investigated under the authority of Bishop Pierre Bertrand of Autun, with canonical inquiries conducted by Jean Jasseron, resulting in official documentation of the miracle. The blood-stained cloth was reverently preserved and placed in a tabernacle. Over the centuries, it has been solemnly exposed on the feast of Corpus Christi in the church of Blanot and remains venerated to this day.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous ecclesiastical investigations and the enduring preservation of the blood-stained cloth without degradation.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region and became a lasting sign affirming the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist, with public veneration continuing for centuries.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bordeaux

location.address: Church of St. Eulalia (Rue Mazarin), Bordeaux; relic preserved at La Solitude, Martillac

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of Jesus giving a blessing)
description: Jesus appeared giving a blessing for more than twenty minutes in the Host exposed for public adoration.
narrative: The Eucharistic Miracle of Bordeaux occurred in 1822, about twenty months after the founding of the religious Community established by the Venerable Father Pierre Noailles. During Eucharistic Benediction in the Church of St. Eulalia on Rue Mazarin, Abbot Delort—substituting that day for Father Noailles—exposed the Blessed Sacrament. Immediately after the blessing, an apparition of Jesus giving a blessing became visible in the Host. A great number of faithful present contemplated the image for more than twenty minutes, and at least one witness testified to hearing the words, “I am He who is.” The event was investigated and approved by ecclesiastical authorities, including the Archbishop of Bordeaux, Monsignor d’Aviau, who personally heard the testimonies. Today, the Chapel of the Miracle can be visited, and the precious relic of the monstrance associated with the apparition is venerated at La Solitude in Martillac.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by extensive eyewitness testimony and ecclesiastical approval following formal evaluation; no laboratory testing was applicable to the visionary nature of the miracle.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in 19th-century France, confirmed belief in the Real Presence, and remains a living focus of prayer through continued veneration of the associated relic.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Dijon

location.address: Basilica of Saint Michael the Archangel, Dijon

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host with image of Christ imprinted)
description: After being cut with a knife, a consecrated Host bled and revealed an image of Christ seated on a semicircular throne.
narrative: In 1430, a woman in Monaco purchased a second-hand monstrance which, unknown to her, still contained a consecrated Host that had likely been stolen. Ignorant of the Real Presence, she attempted to remove the Host using a knife. Immediately, living Blood flowed from the Host and then dried, leaving imprinted upon it the image of the Lord seated on a semicircular throne, accompanied by instruments of the Passion. Disturbed, the woman brought the Host to Canon Anelon, who safeguarded it. The miracle soon became known to Pope Eugene IV, who wished to gift the Host to Duke Philip of Burgundy; the Duke in turn donated it to the city of Dijon. The miraculous Host was preserved and venerated for more than 350 years in the Basilica of Saint Michael the Archangel. In 1794, during the French Revolution, the church was requisitioned as a temple of the so-called ‘goddess of reason,’ and the miraculous Host was burned. Numerous documents and works of art, including stained-glass windows in the Cathedral of Dijon, continue to attest to the event.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous documentation, papal correspondence, and a long history of public veneration; the Host’s preservation and iconographic imprint were widely recorded before its destruction in 1794.
significance: The miracle strongly affirmed belief in the Real Presence and left a lasting devotional and artistic legacy in Dijon, even after the relic’s destruction during the Revolution.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Douai

location.address: Church of Saint Peter (Église Saint-Pierre), Douai

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Levitation of the Host and apparition of the Child Jesus)
description: After being dropped during Communion, a consecrated Host rose by itself and was followed by the apparition of a Child Jesus.
narrative: On Easter Day in 1254, in the Church of St. Amato in Douai, a priest accidentally dropped a consecrated Host while distributing Holy Communion. As he bent down to retrieve it, the Host rose by itself and placed itself upon the purificator. Shortly afterward, a wonderful Child appeared in its place, visible to all the faithful and religious present. The event was witnessed by many and quickly spread. Bishop Thomas de Cantimpré of Cambrai, an eyewitness and theologian, personally investigated the miracle and later described seeing the face of Christ crowned with thorns and drops of blood on the Host. The miracle was commemorated annually, and the relic was preserved and honored for centuries. During the French Revolution the Host was hidden to prevent profanation, and in 1854 it was rediscovered beneath the altar of the Church of Saint Peter in Douai, accompanied by a signed Latin attestation identifying it as the true Host of the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented by contemporaneous eyewitness accounts, including Bishop Thomas de Cantimpré, liturgical commemorations, and a written attestation preserved with the rediscovered Host.
significance: The miracle powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence, inspired centuries of public devotion in Douai, and remains a living focus of Eucharistic prayer and veneration.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Faverney

location.address: Minor Basilica of Our Lady of the Assumption, Faverney

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Levitation and preservation of the Blessed Sacrament)
description: After a fire destroyed the altar, the monstrance containing the Host was found suspended in midair and perfectly intact.
narrative: On the Vigil of Pentecost in 1608, the monks of Faverney exposed the Blessed Sacrament for public adoration. During the night, a fire broke out and destroyed the altar and sacred furnishings, yet the monstrance containing the consecrated Host remained unharmed. When the church was opened the next morning, the monstrance was discovered suspended in midair above the ashes, perfectly intact. The phenomenon continued for several days in the presence of large crowds of faithful and clergy. A provisional altar was prepared, and only after Holy Mass was celebrated did the monstrance slowly descend onto the altar by itself. Canonical investigations followed, and the miracle was officially recognized by ecclesiastical authorities. The miraculous Host has been preserved and venerated ever since, drawing pilgrims annually to Faverney.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through extensive eyewitness testimony and formal canonical investigations describing the sustained levitation and preservation of the Blessed Sacrament after the fire.
significance: One of the most celebrated Eucharistic miracles in France, the event profoundly strengthened Eucharistic faith during a time of religious turmoil and remains a major pilgrimage site.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of La Rochelle

location.address: Cathedral of Saint Louis, La Rochelle

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Instantaneous healing at Holy Communion)
description: A boy paralyzed and mute for years was instantly healed after receiving Holy Communion during Easter Mass.
narrative: During Easter of 1461, Mrs. Jehan Leclerc brought her twelve-year-old son Bartholomé to the parish church of St. Bertrand in La Rochelle. The boy had been paralyzed and unable to speak since the age of seven following a serious fall. At Mass, Bartholomé indicated to his mother that he desired to receive Holy Communion. Initially hesitant because the boy had not been able to go to Confession due to his muteness, the priest was eventually persuaded. Upon receiving the Blessed Sacrament, Bartholomé immediately felt a mysterious warmth throughout his body, stood up, and began to speak. He was completely cured of both paralysis and muteness. The event was carefully recorded in a painted manuscript, which remains preserved in the Cathedral of La Rochelle as authoritative testimony to the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous written documentation, notably the painted manuscript preserved in the Cathedral of La Rochelle, detailing the eyewitness accounts of the healing.
significance: The miracle strengthened faith in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist and became a lasting testimony to the healing power of Holy Communion in La Rochelle.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Les Ulmes

location.address: Parish Church of Les Ulmes, Diocese of Angers

date.displayDate: June 2, 1668 (Saturday of the Octave of Corpus Christi)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of Christ in place of the Host)
description: During Eucharistic adoration, the Host appeared as the figure of a man clothed in white with luminous features.
narrative: On June 2, 1668, during public adoration of the Blessed Sacrament in the parish church of Les Ulmes, the pastor, Fr. Nicolas Nezan, was incensing the monstrance while the hymn Pange Lingua was being sung. At the verse “Verbum caro Panem verum,” the consecrated Host was no longer visible; instead, the figure of a man appeared within the monstrance. Witnesses described light-brown hair falling over his back, a luminous face, hands crossed over one another, and a white tunic covering the body. The apparition lasted for more than fifteen minutes and was visible both when the Blessed Sacrament was on the tabernacle and when it was moved to the altar so the faithful could observe it more closely. The pastor immediately informed Bishop Henry Arnauld of Angers, who ordered a canonical inquiry. After examination, the Bishop authorized public devotion to the miracle. The event was widely publicized, documented in theological works, and commemorated annually for centuries. The miraculous Host was preserved for over 130 years and was devoutly consumed during the French Revolution by the Vicar of Puy-Notre-Dame to prevent profanation.
scientificEvidence: The miracle was formally investigated by episcopal authority and documented in pastoral letters, engravings, and theological works of the 17th century, providing detailed eyewitness descriptions.
significance: The miracle deeply strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, received formal episcopal approval, and remained an important reference point in later Eucharistic congresses and theological studies.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Marseille-en-Beauvais

location.address: Parish Church of Marseille-en-Beauvais; Chapel of the Sacred Hosts

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Hosts preserved intact after desecration)
description: Consecrated Hosts discarded in a field were found the next day perfectly intact despite a heavy snowstorm.
narrative: In January 1533, thieves stole a ciborium containing consecrated Hosts from the parish church of Marseille-en-Beauvais and discarded the Hosts in a field. During the night, a strong snowstorm covered the area. The following day, a man named Jean Mousquet noticed a rock on the roadside that was free of snow. Lifting it, he discovered the consecrated Hosts underneath, found miraculously intact and unharmed despite exposure to the elements. He immediately informed the parish priest, Father Prothais, who recovered the Hosts with the faithful in solemn procession. A cross was erected at the discovery site, and numerous healings and acts of devotion followed. To accommodate pilgrims, the Chapel of the Sacred Hosts was eventually built. Despite these graces, some later attempted to profane the Hosts, which were ultimately destroyed; nevertheless, the miracle remained deeply rooted in local devotion. Each year, a solemn Mass is celebrated on January 2 in remembrance of the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by detailed historical accounts describing the intact condition of the Hosts after severe weather exposure and by recorded testimonies of healings.
significance: The event reinforced belief in the Real Presence, inspired widespread devotion and pilgrimages, and left a lasting liturgical commemoration in Marseille-en-Beauvais.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Paris (Miracle des Billettes)

location.address: Former Church of Saint-Jean-en-Grève; Chapel des Billettes (Rue des Jardins, later Rue du Dieu-Bouilli)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host, levitation, and cruciform apparition)
description: A consecrated Host stabbed, burned, and boiled freed itself miraculously, bled, hovered in midair, and took the form of a crucifix.
narrative: During Easter of 1290, a man named Jonathas, who harbored hatred toward the Catholic Faith and denied the Real Presence, obtained a consecrated Host in Paris with the intent to desecrate it. He stabbed the Host with a knife, causing it to bleed profusely and fill the container in which it was placed. Panic-stricken, he threw the Host into the fire, but it emerged unharmed. He then cast it into boiling water; the Host rose by itself from the water, hovered in midair, and took the form of a crucifix. Terrified, Jonathas placed the Host in the basin of a pious woman from the parish of Saint-Jean-en-Grève, who immediately brought it to her pastor. The miracle was widely attested by documents and chroniclers, including the Italian historian Giovanni Villani and Archbishop Rupp of Paris. King Philip the Fair confiscated the house of Jonathas, known thereafter as the ‘House of Miracles,’ and transformed it into a chapel following papal authorization from Pope Boniface VIII. The street became known as ‘Rue du Dieu bouilli’ (‘Street of God-Boiled’). The Host was preserved for centuries in a reliquary at the Church of Saint-Jean-en-Grève until it was lost during the French Revolution.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by extensive medieval documentation, royal records, episcopal histories, and later critical historical studies, including a 1954 scholarly examination by Moreau-Rendu affirming the authenticity of the sources.
significance: One of the most famous medieval Eucharistic miracles, it deeply shaped Parisian devotion, inspired royal and papal action, and left a lasting imprint on the city’s religious geography and liturgical memory.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Pressac

location.address: Church of St. Just, Pressac (Diocese of Poitiers)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Preservation of the Host during fire)
description: After a church fire fused the chalice, the Host was found intact beneath a tin bubble formed on the chalice’s foot.
narrative: On Holy Thursday in 1643, after Mass and Communion, the priest placed the chalice containing the reserved Host in the repository near the altar of the Blessed Virgin. Two candles left burning likely ignited a fire while the church was closed. When townspeople forced entry, the repository and painting were destroyed; nearly the entire chalice had fused into droplets of tin, leaving only the foot. Above it, a tin bubble had formed, and beneath this bubble the consecrated Host was found completely intact, having withstood both flames and molten metal. The vicar, Simon Sauvage, brought the bubbling remnant to the main altar for all to see. The Host—lightly reddened at the edges—was consumed the following morning during the Divine Office of Good Friday. Abbot François du Theil recorded sworn testimony and submitted it to Bishop Henri Louis Chastagnier de la Roche-Posay of Poitiers, who formally authorized public devotion. The miracle has been commemorated ever since, and stained-glass windows in the Church of St. Just depict the event’s phases.
scientificEvidence: Canonical testimonies document the fusion of the chalice into tin droplets and the intact Host preserved beneath a formed tin bubble; the physical remnants (chalice foot) and iconographic records corroborate the accounts.
significance: The miracle affirmed Eucharistic faith during a time of peril, received episcopal approval, and left enduring material and artistic witnesses that continue to testify to the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Augsburg

location.address: Convent of the Holy Cross (Heilig Kreuz), Augsburg

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into bleeding Flesh)
description: A stolen consecrated Host was later found transformed into bleeding Flesh and has remained preserved for veneration.
narrative: In 1194, a woman in Augsburg, devoted to the Eucharist, stole a consecrated Host to keep it at home during a time when churches were closed to Eucharistic worship. She hid the Host in a wax container inside a cupboard. Years later, tormented by remorse, she returned the Host to the superior of the Convent of the Holy Cross, Father Berthold. When the priest opened the wax covering, he discovered that the Eucharist had been transformed into bleeding Flesh. Bishop Udalsk of Augsburg ordered the Host transferred in solemn procession to the cathedral and exhibited in a crystal reliquary for public veneration. Over time, the Host reportedly grew and swelled, and bleeding recurred, prompting further episcopal oversight. Historical sources record additional extraordinary signs, including apparitions associated with the relic. In 1200, Count Rechberg donated a silver opening for the placement of the Host. Through the centuries, several analyses were conducted, consistently confirming the presence of human Flesh and Blood. Today, the relic—known locally as *Wunderbarliches Gutes* (“The Miraculous Good”)—is preserved and cared for by the Dominican Fathers at the Convent of the Holy Cross in Augsburg.
scientificEvidence: Across centuries, multiple examinations and analyses consistently reported the presence of human Flesh and Blood in the relic, as documented in historical records held in Augsburg’s civic state library.
significance: One of the most enduring Eucharistic miracles in Germany, Augsburg has been continuously venerated for centuries and stands as a prominent testimony to belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Benningen

location.address: Riedkapelle zum Hochwürdigen Gut; Parish of St. Martin, Memmingen (custody)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host after desecration)
description: A consecrated Host began to bleed profusely after being stolen and desecrated by millers.
narrative: In 1216, in the village of Benningen, two millers who were at odds with one another stole a consecrated Host after Holy Communion and carried it to a mill, intending to profane it. During the Feast of St. Gregory, the Host began to bleed so abundantly that the entire village and the Bishop learned of the event. The blasphemous miller repented and confessed his wrongdoing. The Bishop of Augsburg, Frederick, took custody of the Host and deposited it in a precious container in the Church of St. Martin in Memmingen. In the years following, the faithful began construction of a chapel at Benningen—later known as the Riedkapelle zum Hochwürdigen Gut—which was rebuilt and enlarged between 1674 and 1718 to accommodate pilgrims. Each year on the Feast of Corpus Christi, the parish of Benningen processes to the Riedkapelle to commemorate the miracle, which has remained a focal point of local devotion for centuries.
scientificEvidence: The event is documented in contemporaneous accounts describing the profuse bleeding of the Host and subsequent episcopal intervention; artistic cycles and chapel records preserve the historical testimony.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic faith in the region, inspired penitence and conversion, and established a lasting pilgrimage tradition centered on Corpus Christi devotion.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bettbrunn

location.address: Church of the Holy Savior (San Salvatore), Bettbrunn

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Immovable Host lifted after episcopal vow)
description: A consecrated Host that fell to the ground could not be lifted until the bishop vowed to build a chapel in its honor.
narrative: In 1125, near the small farm of Viehbrunn, a devout farmer—unable to attend Mass regularly—secretly took a consecrated Host home, concealing it in a hollowed walking stick so he could pray before it daily. Months later, while tending livestock, he impulsively threw the stick; the Host fell to the ground. Stricken with remorse, he tried to retrieve it, but the Host could not be lifted. Neither the parish priest of Tholling nor others succeeded. Bishop Hartwich of Regensburg came with his clergy and was able to lift the Host only after promising to build a chapel on the spot in honor of the Blessed Sacrament. The chapel was completed that same year, giving rise to the village of Bettbrunn and the Church of the Holy Savior. The relic was kept there until a fire in 1330 destroyed the building; the church was later rebuilt, preserving a pillar saved from the fire as a memorial.
scientificEvidence: The event is documented by contemporaneous ecclesiastical accounts describing the immovable Host and the bishop’s successful retrieval following a vowed act, along with enduring architectural and devotional records.
significance: The miracle founded Bettbrunn as a pilgrimage site, strengthened Eucharistic devotion, and led to the construction of the Church of the Holy Savior dedicated to the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Erding

location.address: Sanctuary of the Most Precious Blood, Erding

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host flying and recovered through episcopal intervention)
description: A consecrated Host stolen by a peasant escaped his hands, flew through the air repeatedly, and was recovered only through the Bishop’s intervention.
narrative: On Holy Thursday in 1417, a poor peasant of Erding, believing the Blessed Sacrament to be a kind of amulet that could bring prosperity, secretly took a consecrated Host after receiving Communion and hid it in his clothing. Struck by remorse during his journey, he attempted to return the Host, but it slipped from his hands and flew into the air, disappearing from sight. Terrified, he alerted the parish priest, who went to the spot where the Host had vanished. The priest saw the Host resting on a clump of earth, emitting a bright light, but when he tried to pick it up, it again flew away. The Bishop was summoned and came personally to the site; even then, the Host once more rose into the air. Only after the Bishop and the faithful resolved to build a chapel in honor of the Eucharistic Wonder was the Host finally recovered. A chapel was immediately constructed on the site, and numerous cures and wonders were soon attributed to devotion to this miracle. Because of the growing number of pilgrims, a larger baroque sanctuary was built between 1675 and 1677 and dedicated to the Most Precious Blood. The sanctuary, enriched with relics including that of the Most Precious Blood of Christ, has since remained a major place of pilgrimage and has been under the care of the monks of St. Paul of the Desert since 1992.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through detailed historical and ecclesiastical accounts describing the repeated levitation of the Host, its luminous appearance, and the Bishop’s direct involvement in its recovery.
significance: The miracle led to the foundation of one of Bavaria’s most important Eucharistic pilgrimage sites and remains a powerful testimony to belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Kranenburg bei Kleve (Miracle of the Miraculous Crucifix)

location.address: Church of St. Peter and Paul, Kranenburg (District of Kleve)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous Crucifix arising from a Host)
description: A consecrated Host thrown near a tree later gave rise to a perfectly formed crucifix discovered inside the tree.
narrative: Around 1280, in the town of Kranenburg in the district of Kleve, a shepherd who had received Holy Communion found himself unable to swallow the consecrated Host because of illness. In confusion and fear, he threw the Host near a tree in a garden. Stricken by remorse, he later confessed the incident to a priest, who searched unsuccessfully for the Host. Several years afterward, the same tree was cut down and split in two. At that moment, a perfectly carved crucifix fell from the trunk, astonishing all present. News of the prodigy spread rapidly, and the crucifix was venerated as a miraculous sign born of the Eucharist. On the site where the crucifix was found, a church was built, which still stands today and continues to attract numerous pilgrims. Bishops of Cologne and the Counts of Kleve promoted devotion to the Miraculous Crucifix, granting indulgences. In 1444, a larger Gothic church was constructed to house the relic, which remains one of the most important examples of Gothic devotional art in the Lower Rhine region.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by medieval documents, ecclesiastical records, and the enduring physical relic of the Miraculous Crucifix preserved and venerated in the church.
significance: The miracle established Kranenburg as a major pilgrimage site and powerfully reinforced belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist through a lasting devotional and artistic legacy.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Regensburg

location.address: Sanctuary of the Savior (near Regensburg; Ratisbonne)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Living Crucifix and exhibition of the Blessed Sacrament)
description: During Mass, a wooden crucifix came to life and Christ took the chalice from the priest to show the Eucharist to the faithful.
narrative: On Holy Thursday, March 25, 1255, a priest of Ratisbonne was carrying Holy Viaticum to a dying person when an unexpected storm caused a stream to overflow at the city entrance. While crossing a plank placed over the water, he slipped and dropped the ciborium containing the consecrated Hosts. As an act of reparation, the priest, faithful, and civil authorities resolved that same day to build a chapel on the site of the accident. On September 8, 1255, Bishop Albert consecrated the chapel in honor of the Savior, and the Blessed Sacrament was carried there in solemn procession, soon drawing many pilgrims. Two years later, while a priest was celebrating Mass in the chapel, he was assailed by doubts about the Real Presence and hesitated at the elevation of the chalice. Suddenly, a sound was heard from the altar, and the wooden crucifix above it came to life: the Lord slowly extended His arms, took the chalice from the priest’s hands, and exhibited the Blessed Sacrament for the adoration of the faithful. The priest repented and begged forgiveness; the Lord then returned the chalice as a sign of pardon. The miraculous crucifix is still preserved in Regensburg and continues to be venerated by pilgrims.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by detailed medieval ecclesiastical accounts describing the events, the preserved miraculous crucifix, and the longstanding tradition of pilgrimage to the site.
significance: The miracle profoundly strengthened faith in the Real Presence, led to the foundation of a sanctuary, and remains one of Germany’s most notable medieval Eucharistic testimonies.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Walldürn

location.address: Minor Basilica of St. George, Walldürn

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into Blood forming image of Christ)
description: During Mass, consecrated wine spilled onto the corporal and transformed into Blood forming the image of the Crucified Christ.
narrative: In 1330, while celebrating Holy Mass in Walldürn, the priest Heinrich Otto accidentally overturned the chalice containing the consecrated wine onto the corporal. Immediately, the spilled wine transformed into Blood and formed the distinct image of the Crucified Christ surrounded by eleven crowned heads, representing the Apostles. Overcome by fear, the priest concealed the corporal beneath the altar and did not reveal the miracle for many years. Near the end of his life, he confessed the event, and the corporal was solemnly recovered. From the beginning, the relic inspired deep devotion, numerous conversions, and miraculous healings. The miracle was officially confirmed by Pope Eugene IV in 1445, who granted indulgences to pilgrims. The corporal is preserved today in the Minor Basilica of St. George in Walldürn, where it is displayed on a side altar. Each year, thousands of pilgrims visit Walldürn to venerate the miraculous corporal, making it one of Germany’s most important Eucharistic pilgrimage sites.
scientificEvidence: The relic consists of a corporal bearing dried Blood forming a clear iconographic image of the Crucified Christ, preserved and venerated for centuries and documented in detailed historical records, including a comprehensive account written in 1589 by the monk Hoffius.
significance: The miracle established Walldürn as a major center of Eucharistic devotion in Germany, affirmed belief in the Real Presence, and continues to attract large-scale pilgrimage and veneration.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Weingarten (Most Precious Blood of Jesus)

location.address: Basilica of St. Martin, former Benedictine Abbey of Weingarten

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Relic of the Most Precious Blood of Jesus)
description: A relic of the Most Precious Blood of Jesus has been venerated at Weingarten for over nine centuries.
narrative: For more than 900 years, the faithful have venerated a relic of the Most Precious Blood of Jesus at the Benedictine Monastery of Weingarten. According to historical tradition, the Roman soldier Longinus carried the Precious Blood from Calvary to Mantua, where it was preserved and later divided into portions given to rulers and popes, including Charlemagne. An ancient document records that in 1055 Emperor Henry III of the Franks received a portion of the Precious Blood, which he bequeathed to Count Baldwin of Flanders. Baldwin passed the relic to his daughter Judith, who in turn gave it to her husband, Guelfo IV of Bavaria. Guelfo entrusted the relic to the Benedictine monks of Weingarten, then led by Abbot Wilichon. The solemn enshrinement took place on March 4, 1094, after which numerous papal indulgences were granted to the abbey, making it a major religious center. Each year, Weingarten celebrates the renowned ‘Ride of the Blood,’ a grand procession involving thousands of riders and clergy, honoring the Precious Blood relic that remains preserved in the Basilica of St. Martin.
scientificEvidence: The authenticity and origin of the relic are supported by medieval documents, including a letter dated March 1, 1278, confirming its Mantuan provenance, and by continuous historical custody and veneration.
significance: Weingarten is one of Europe’s most important centers of devotion to the Most Precious Blood of Jesus, fostering centuries of pilgrimage, liturgical celebration, and affirmation of Eucharistic faith.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Wilsnack

location.address: Church of St. Nikolai (St. Nicholas), Bad Wilsnack

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Hosts preserved after fire)
description: After a devastating fire, three consecrated Hosts were found intact and bleeding continuously among the ruins of the parish church.
narrative: In August 1383, the village of Wilsnack was sacked, robbed, and set ablaze by Count Heinrich von Bülow, leaving the parish church in ruins. Amid the destruction, three consecrated Hosts were discovered perfectly intact and bleeding continuously. The Hosts were recovered and venerated, and numerous miracles were soon reported. One notable case involved Count Dietrich von Wenckstern, who doubted the authenticity of the bleeding Hosts and consequently lost his eyesight; his vision was restored only after he repented of his doubt. The miracle spread rapidly, and in 1384 the Bishop of Havelberg officially confirmed the phenomenon. Pope Urban VI contributed funds for rebuilding the church, joined by offerings from regional bishops. Wilsnack became one of Europe’s most important pilgrimage destinations until the 1500s, enabling the construction of the large Gothic brick Church of St. Nikolai dedicated to the miracle. Although the monstrance containing the relics was destroyed in a fire in 1522, extensive written testimonies and artworks documenting the miracle have survived.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by contemporaneous ecclesiastical confirmations, papal bulls (approved by Pope Eugene IV in 1447), eyewitness accounts of continuous bleeding, and a substantial body of historical documentation and devotional art.
significance: One of the most influential medieval Eucharistic miracles, Wilsnack shaped European pilgrimage culture for centuries and strongly reinforced belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Alkmaar

location.address: Cathedral of Saint Lawrence (Sint-Laurenskerk), Alkmaar

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into Blood)
description: During Mass, consecrated wine spilled onto the altar and chasuble and miraculously transformed into Blood.
narrative: On May 1, 1429, in the Cathedral of Saint Lawrence in Alkmaar, a priest named Folkert was celebrating his first Mass, assisted by Father Volpert Schult. Shortly after the consecration, Father Folkert accidentally knocked over the chalice, spilling the consecrated wine onto the altar and his chasuble. Immediately, the wine transformed into living Blood. After Mass, attempts were made to clean and even burn the blood-stained portion of the chasuble, but the stains could not be removed and reappeared after sewing. The blood-soaked chasuble was preserved as a precious relic. Numerous canonical investigations were conducted, and in 1433 the Bishop officially approved devotion surrounding the miracle. To this day, the blood-stained chasuble is preserved in a reliquary shaped like an angel and venerated in the Cathedral of Saint Lawrence in Alkmaar.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by multiple canonical investigations conducted shortly after the event and by the enduring preservation of the blood-stained chasuble, which resisted all attempts at removal.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the Netherlands, received formal episcopal approval, and remains a lasting testimony to belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Amsterdam

location.address: Site of the Miracle (former house of Ysbrand Dommer), near Oude Kerk; Chapel of the Beguines (later devotion)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host preserved from fire and suspended in air)
description: A consecrated Host thrown into a fire was found intact and miraculously suspended in midair among the flames.
narrative: On March 12, 1345, a few days before Easter, Ysbrand Dommer of Amsterdam, gravely ill and believing he was near death, received Holy Communion at his home from the parish priest of the Oude Kerk. Shortly afterward, he vomited into a basin; the contents, including the consecrated Host, were thrown by his maid into the lit fireplace. The following day, Ysbrand unexpectedly recovered his health. When the maid approached the fireplace to tend the fire, she saw a brilliant light and discovered the Host completely intact, suspended in midair amid the flames. Neighbors rushed in and witnessed the prodigy. The Host was wrapped in a linen cloth and taken to the parish priest, but three times it miraculously reappeared in Ysbrand’s house, requiring the priest to retrieve it again. It was then decided to convert the house into a chapel. On Easter Sunday, eyewitnesses and the mayor of Amsterdam compiled a sworn report that was delivered to Bishop Jan van Arkel of Utrecht, who immediately authorized devotion to the miracle. In 1452 the chapel was destroyed by fire, yet the monstrance containing the miraculous Host remained intact. In 1665, the relic was transferred to a chapel of the Beguines, though it was later stolen by unknown persons. Today, perpetual Eucharistic adoration is maintained in memory of the miracle, and each year Amsterdam holds the silent procession known as the *Stille Omgang* on the eve of Palm Sunday.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by sworn eyewitness reports, an official episcopal investigation and authorization, repeated inexplicable reappearances of the Host, and the documented survival of the monstrance in later fires.
significance: One of the most famous Eucharistic miracles in Northern Europe, the Miracle of Amsterdam has inspired uninterrupted public devotion for centuries and remains commemorated by the annual *Stille Omgang* procession.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bergen

location.address: Church of Saints Peter and Paul; River Scheldt, Bergen op Zoom

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Recovered Hosts stained with Blood)
description: Consecrated Hosts thrown into a river were later found floating and stained with Blood.
narrative: In 1421, in the city of Bergen op Zoom, the pastor of the Church of Saints Peter and Paul experienced persistent doubts about the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. Because of his lack of devotion toward the Blessed Sacrament, one day after celebrating Mass he took the remaining consecrated Hosts and threw them into the river Scheldt. Several months later, fishermen discovered the Hosts floating on the water, visibly stained with coagulated Blood. News of the prodigy spread rapidly, and many pilgrims came to venerate the recovered Hosts. Ecclesiastical authorities approved devotion to the miracle. During the Protestant Reformation, public veneration was suppressed for a long period, but Catholics continued to preserve the memory of the miracle privately. Devotion was officially restored in the twentieth century, and numerous public events and commemorations have since taken place in Bergen to honor the Eucharistic miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through historical ecclesiastical accounts describing the recovery of the Hosts from the river and their visible bloodstains, along with later approvals and commemorations recorded in local church history.
significance: The miracle reaffirmed faith in the Real Presence, endured periods of suppression, and remains a lasting symbol of Eucharistic devotion in the Netherlands.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Boxmeer

location.address: Church of Saints Peter and Paul, Boxmeer

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into Blood)
description: During Mass, the consecrated wine bubbled out of the chalice, transformed into Blood, and coagulated on the corporal.
narrative: In 1400, during Holy Mass in the Church of Saints Peter and Paul at Boxmeer, Father Arnoldus Groen doubted the Real Presence immediately after the consecration. Suddenly, the consecrated wine began to bubble out of the chalice as if boiling and splashed onto the corporal, transforming into Blood. When the priest, terrified, asked God to forgive his doubts, the bubbling ceased. The Blood that had fallen onto the corporal coagulated into a solid lump about the size of a walnut. The relic—the corporal with the coagulated Blood—has been preserved without change over time and is kept in a reliquary. Numerous documents, stone tablets, paintings, and stained-glass windows attest to the event. The anniversary of the miracle is commemorated each year with a solemn procession, and several Popes, including Clement XI, Benedict XIV, Pius IX, and Leo XIII, expressed particular devotion to this miracle.
scientificEvidence: Historical records attest to the visible transformation of the consecrated wine into Blood, its coagulation into a stable mass, and the long-term preservation of the relic without alteration.
significance: The miracle reinforced belief in the Real Presence, inspired enduring public devotion and annual processions, and remains one of the Netherlands’ most venerated Eucharistic testimonies.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Boxtel–Hoogstraten

location.address: St. Peter’s Church, Boxtel; St. Catherine’s Church, Hoogstraten

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into Blood)
description: After the chalice was accidentally overturned during Mass, the consecrated white wine transformed into Blood and permanently stained the corporal and altar cloth.
narrative: Around 1380, the priest Eligius van der Aker was celebrating Mass at St. Peter’s Church in Boxtel, at the altar of the Three Kings. Immediately after the consecration, he accidentally knocked over the chalice containing consecrated white wine. The spilled wine instantly changed into Blood, staining the corporal and the altar cloth. After Mass, the priest attempted unsuccessfully to remove the Blood stains and, frightened, hid the linens under his bed. Only on his deathbed did he reveal the event to his confessor, Fr. Henrijk van Meerheim, who informed Cardinal Pileus, apostolic legate of Pope Urban VI. Following a thorough investigation, Cardinal Pileus authorized public veneration of the relics by a decree dated June 25, 1380.
