Due to later religious conflicts, the relics were transferred in 1652 to Hoogstraten, near the Belgian border. In 1924, after repeated petitions, the Blood-stained corporal was returned to Boxtel. Each year on the feast of the Holy Trinity, a solemn procession commemorates the miracle and the relic is exposed for public veneration.
scientificEvidence: Historical ecclesiastical documentation records the immediate transformation of the consecrated wine into Blood, the permanence of the stains despite attempts at removal, and the formal canonical investigation culminating in the decree of Cardinal Pileus.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, received formal ecclesiastical approval, and continues to be commemorated through annual public processions and veneration of the relic.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Breda–Niervaart

location.address: Collegiate Church of Our Lady, Breda; village of Niervaart

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Stolen Host found intact)
description: A consecrated Host stolen by a soldier was later found buried in the ground, perfectly preserved.
narrative: On June 24, 1300, during a period of military occupation, a soldier stole a consecrated Host in the village of Niervaart near Breda. Sometime later, a farmer named Jan Bautoen discovered a mysterious light shining from the earth while working his field. Digging at the spot, he found the Sacred Host hidden beneath a clod of soil, completely intact and uncorrupted despite the passage of time. The Host was placed in a precious container and brought to the pastor of Niervaart. News of the miracle spread rapidly, and the faithful began to venerate the Eucharist. In 1449, the Blessed Sacrament was transferred to the Collegiate Church of Our Lady in Breda, where a richly decorated monstrance was made for its preservation. During later religious conflicts, the relic itself was lost, but devotion endured. In the 20th century, public veneration was solemnly restored in Breda, and to this day annual processions and prayers commemorate the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by a formal episcopal investigation conducted by the Bishop of Liège and by extensive historical documentation describing the Host’s preservation and discovery.
significance: The miracle deeply strengthened Eucharistic faith in the region, became one of the best-documented medieval Eucharistic miracles, and continues to be commemorated through public devotion and processions.

name: Eucharistic Miracles of Meerssen

location.address: Basilica of the Blessed Sacrament, Meerssen

Today, the Basilica of the Blessed Sacrament in Meerssen remains a major pilgrimage destination, and the precious relic of the miracle is solemnly carried in procession each year on the octave of Corpus Christi.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Stiphout

location.address: Saint Trudo’s Church, Stiphout

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated Hosts preserved from fire)

The elderly pastor, Jan Hocaerts, alerted the villagers, and a group of faithful led by Jan Baloys resolved to rescue the Blessed Sacrament. Since the doors could not be opened, Baloys was lowered through a window near the altar after breaking the glass. Inside, he witnessed that although the church had been destroyed by fire, the flames were being held back from the area surrounding the tabernacle. He opened it, removed the ciborium containing the consecrated Hosts, and carried them safely outside. The faithful immediately recognized the event as miraculous. The church was later rebuilt, and the Hosts remained intact until 1557. Due to later historical upheavals and religious wars, the relics were eventually lost. The miracle has been documented in numerous records, commemorated in artwork still displayed in Saint Trudo’s Church, and is venerated annually by the people of Stiphout, especially on the feast of Corpus Christi.

significance: The event strengthened Eucharistic faith in the region, inspired annual Corpus Christi devotion, and remains a lasting symbol of belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Kraków

location.address: Village of Wawel (near Kraków); Church of Corpus Christi, Kraków

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Hosts emitting a supernatural light)
description: Consecrated Hosts stolen and abandoned in a marsh emitted a brilliant light visible for kilometers.

Discovering that the monstrance was not made of solid gold, they discarded it with the Hosts into a muddy marsh. When darkness fell, villagers observed mysterious, intense flashes of light emanating from the marsh, visible from several kilometers away. Frightened witnesses informed the Bishop of Kraków, who ordered three days of fasting and prayer. On the third day, he led a solemn procession to the marsh, where the monstrance and the Hosts were found intact and unbroken, clearly the source of the light. The faithful celebrated the miracle, and in the same year King Casimir III the Great ordered the construction of the Church of Corpus Christi in Kraków in its honor. Paintings, documents, and depositions commemorating the miracle are preserved in that church, and the event is celebrated annually on the feast of Corpus Christi.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented by contemporary ecclesiastical records, sworn depositions, and enduring iconographic evidence depicting the luminous phenomenon and recovery of the Hosts.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in medieval Poland, inspired the founding of the Church of Corpus Christi in Kraków, and remains a lasting testimony to belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Głotowo

location.address: Eucharistic Sanctuary of Głotowo (Dobro Miasto area)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Luminous Host discovered after burial)
description: A consecrated Host buried during an invasion was later found intact, emitting a brilliant light, when oxen knelt in adoration.
narrative: In 1290, during the invasion of the Lithuanians, a priest from the village of Głotowo buried in a field a silver ciborium plated in gold containing a consecrated Host, which he had inadvertently left inside. The village and its church were destroyed, and none of the survivors knew of the hidden Eucharist. Years later, in springtime, a farmer plowing the field noticed strange behavior from his oxen: they suddenly bowed to the ground and knelt in adoration. From the earth there emanated an intense, brilliant light. Digging at the spot, the farmer uncovered a small ciborium covered with soil that contained a perfect Host, white as snow. News of the prodigy spread quickly; local authorities organized a solemn procession to bring the Host to the church of Dobro Miasto. According to an ancient chronicle, the Host inexplicably disappeared during the procession and was found again at the very place where it had first been discovered, which was interpreted as a sign designating the site for veneration. Over the centuries devotion grew, and in the eighteenth century the old medieval church was enlarged and consecrated by Bishop Krzysztof Potocki on July 24, 1726. To this day, the shrine of Głotowo welcomes pilgrims who come to venerate the relic of the Host, intact since 1290.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by ancient chronicles, local ecclesiastical records, and continuous pilgrimage tradition centered on the intact Host and the luminous phenomenon described at its discovery.
significance: The miracle established Głotowo as a lasting center of Eucharistic devotion in Poland, affirming belief in the Real Presence and inspiring centuries of pilgrimage and worship.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Legnica

location.address: St. Hyacinth’s Church, Legnica

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into human heart tissue)
description: A consecrated Host that fell during Communion developed a red stain later identified as human heart muscle tissue.
narrative: On December 25, 2013, during Holy Mass at St. Hyacinth’s Church in Legnica, a consecrated Host accidentally fell to the ground during the distribution of Communion. In accordance with Canon Law, it was placed in a container of water and stored in the tabernacle to dissolve. On January 4, 2014, priests observed that the Host had not dissolved and that a red stain covered approximately one-fifth of its surface. Bishop Stefan Cichy immediately established a special theological and scientific commission. Samples were collected on January 26, 2014, and analyzed by independent forensic and medical institutes in Wrocław and Szczecin. The analyses excluded bacteria, fungi, and external contaminants. Histopathological examinations revealed fragments of cross-striated muscle consistent with human myocardial tissue, showing alterations typically seen during agony. Human DNA was identified. The findings were submitted to the Vatican’s Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, which recognized the supernatural nature of the event. On April 10 and April 17, 2016, Bishop Zbigniew Kiernikowski officially announced the results and ordered the preparation of a suitable place for public veneration of the relic.
scientificEvidence: Independent histopathological analyses by multiple forensic medicine institutes identified myocardial fibers consistent with human heart muscle, with structural changes associated with extreme physiological stress, and excluded any natural or microbial causes.
significance: The Legnica miracle is one of the most scientifically documented modern Eucharistic miracles, reinforcing belief in the Real Presence and echoing findings from Lanciano and other approved Eucharistic miracles.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Sokółka

location.address: Church of Saint Anthony of Padua, Sokółka

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into human cardiac muscle tissue)
description: A consecrated Host that fell during Communion developed a blood-red substance later identified as living human heart muscle tissue.
narrative: On October 12, 2008, during the 8:30 AM Holy Mass at the Church of Saint Anthony of Padua in Sokółka, celebrated by Fr. Filip Zdrodowski, a consecrated Host accidentally fell from the priest’s hands during Communion. The Host was placed in a small silver vessel containing water and secured in the sacristy safe. A week later, when the sacristan Sister Julia Dubowska examined the vessel, the Host had partially dissolved and a distinct red substance was visible. The fragment was transferred onto a corporal and stored in the tabernacle. In January 2009, the Curia of Białystok commissioned two independent specialists in pathological anatomy from the Medical University of Białystok—Professor Maria Elżbieta Sobaniec-Łotowska and Professor Stanisław Sulkowski—to analyze the material. Microscopic and electron microscope examinations revealed numerous bio-morphological indicators characteristic of human cardiac muscle tissue, including segmentation, fragmentation, central nuclei, and structures typical of myocardium fibers undergoing intense contractions in the final phase preceding death. The tissue was found to be inseparably intertwined with the consecrated Host. The analyses excluded blood clots, microbial pigments, bacterial contamination, and any possibility of manipulation. An ecclesiastical commission convened by the Archbishop of Białystok on March 30, 2009 confirmed the continuity and integrity of custody of the Host. On October 14, 2009, the Metropolitan Curia of Białystok officially communicated the findings. The relic is preserved and solemnly carried in procession, drawing large numbers of faithful.
scientificEvidence: Independent histopathological and electron microscope analyses identified living human cardiac muscle tissue showing features of extreme physiological stress, excluded autolysis, microbial origin, or fraud, and confirmed inseparable integration of myocardial fibers with the Host.
significance: One of the most thoroughly investigated modern Eucharistic miracles, Sokółka powerfully reinforces belief in the Real Presence and parallels findings from Legnica and Lanciano.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Alboraya–Almácera

Rescued but heartbroken, the priest was approached by fishermen who had witnessed an astonishing sight: three fish near the shore, each holding a small white disc resembling a Host in its mouth. Without hesitation, the priest returned with another ciborium. The fish were seen almost out of the water, lifting the Hosts like little trophies. Kneeling, the priest extended the chalice and prayed fervently; one by one, the fish deposited the Hosts into the chalice and then swiftly disappeared into the sea. A crowd gathered and witnessed the entire scene. The Hosts were carried back to the church in a solemn procession joined by the whole village. Numerous documents attest to the miracle; a small church was built on the site, its doors adorned with sculpted fish, and paintings and mosaics continue to depict the event, which is commemorated especially at Corpus Christi.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous documentary testimony, enduring iconographic representations (paintings, mosaics, sculpted fish), and continuous local tradition preserved at the commemorative churches.
significance: The event strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, inspired lasting artistic and architectural memorials, and remains a vivid testimony to belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Alcalá

location.address: Jesuit Church (later Cathedral/Magisterial Church), Alcalá

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated Hosts preserved intact)
description: Twenty-four consecrated Hosts stolen and later returned were found perfectly intact after eleven years and verified by medical and theological study.
narrative: In 1597, a thief stole consecrated Hosts along with precious objects from a church near Alcalá, Spain. A few days later, filled with remorse, he confessed his sins at the Jesuit church of Alcalá and returned the Hosts to the priest. Fearing possible poisoning—after recent incidents elsewhere—the Jesuits decided not to consume the Hosts but to place them in a silver box and allow them to decompose naturally. After eleven years, the twenty-four consecrated Hosts were found perfectly intact. The Provincial, Father Luis de la Palma, ordered a further test: the Hosts were placed in a wine cellar alongside unconsecrated hosts. Months later, the unconsecrated hosts had decomposed due to humidity, while the consecrated Hosts remained intact. Six years later, the miracle was made public. New academic, medical, and theological examinations—conducted with the involvement of royal physicians and eminent theologians—confirmed the miraculous nature of the preservation. In 1619 ecclesiastical authorities officially authorized the miracle. The Holy Hosts were publicly adored before King Philip III, who in 1620 presided over a solemn procession with the entire royal family. After the expulsion of the Jesuits, the Hosts were moved to the Magisterial Church. In 1936, during the burning of the church, priests hid the miraculous Hosts before being killed; their hiding place has never been discovered.
scientificEvidence: Extended preservation without decomposition was verified over decades, including comparative testing with unconsecrated hosts under identical conditions; additional medical and theological examinations by royal physicians and scholars affirmed the phenomenon.
significance: The miracle became a major focus of Eucharistic devotion in Spain, received official ecclesiastical approval, involved royal veneration, and remains a powerful testimony to belief in the Real Presence despite the later disappearance of the relics.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Caravaca de la Cruz

location.address: Church and Sanctuary of the Holy Cross, Caravaca de la Cruz

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of Christ during Mass)
description: During Mass celebrated before a Muslim king, Christ appeared in the Host and angels placed a Cross upon the altar.
narrative: In 1231, the Christian priest Don Gínes Pérez Chirinos de Cuenca was captured while preaching among the Moors of the Kingdom of Murcia and brought before the Muslim king Zeyt-Abu-Zeyt. Curious about the Christian faith, the king asked the priest to explain the Holy Mass and then ordered him to celebrate one. Liturgical objects were fetched from Christian territory, but the altar Cross was missing. When the priest realized this, he halted the Mass in distress. At that moment, before the astonished king, two angels appeared and placed a Cross upon the altar. Deeply moved, the priest continued the celebration. At the moment of consecration, the king saw a beautiful infant Jesus appear within the Host, gazing at him with love. Struck by the miracle, the king, his wife, and his family converted to Christianity and were baptized, taking the names Vincent and Elena. From that day, March 3, 1231, the town became known as Caravaca de la Cruz. The miracle was recorded by the Franciscan Father Gilles of Zamora, historian of King Saint Ferdinand. In later centuries, Caravaca was granted the rare privilege of celebrating a perpetual jubilee every seven years at the sanctuary where the Holy Cross is preserved.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by contemporaneous historical testimony, especially that of Franciscan Father Gilles of Zamora, and supported by enduring ecclesiastical tradition and iconographic documentation.
significance: The miracle led to the conversion of a Muslim ruler and his court, established Caravaca as a major center of Eucharistic and Christological devotion, and earned the city recognition as one of the few perpetual jubilee sites in the world.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Cimballa

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Daroca

location.address: Basilica of Santa María de los Sagrados Corporales, Daroca

After the Christians emerged victorious, the commanders requested Communion. When Don Mateo retrieved the corporal, he found the Hosts completely drenched in Blood. Interpreting this as a divine sign, the leaders decided the relic should be entrusted to a city chosen by God. Even today, the blood-stained corporals are preserved and venerated in Daroca, especially in the Basilica of Santa María de los Sagrados Corporales, with annual processions commemorating the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous historical documentation, preserved blood-stained corporals, and centuries of continuous public veneration recorded in ecclesiastical and civic records.
significance: One of Spain’s most famous medieval Eucharistic miracles, it strengthened Eucharistic devotion, influenced regional history, and established Daroca as a major pilgrimage site centered on the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Gerona

location.address: Ancient Benedictine monastery; Cathedral of Gerona

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Flesh)
description: During Communion, a priest who doubted the Real Presence found the Host transformed into living Flesh in his mouth.
narrative: In 1297, during the celebration of Holy Mass in an ancient Benedictine monastery in Gerona, a priest doubted the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. When the moment of Communion arrived, he attempted to consume the consecrated Host but was unable to swallow it, for it had transformed into living Flesh in his mouth. Overcome with fear and awe, he removed the Host and wrapped it in the corporal, placing it on the altar. A nun who was assisting at Mass witnessed the priest’s distress and later saw him remove something from his mouth. After the Mass, the priest confessed his doubt and, upon examining the corporal, discovered a small piece of Flesh dripping with Blood. The miracle became known as the “Holy Doubt.” The relic was preserved for centuries in a reliquary and venerated by the faithful. Unfortunately, during the Spanish Civil War in 1936, the reliquary containing the Incarnate Host and the blood-stained corporal was destroyed.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous eyewitness testimony, long-term preservation and veneration of the Flesh relic, and detailed historical ecclesiastical records.
significance: The miracle powerfully reaffirmed belief in the Real Presence, became a major focus of Eucharistic devotion in Catalonia, and remains an enduring witness despite the loss of the relics in 1936.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Gorkum–El Escorial

location.address: Catholic Church in Gorkum; Royal Monastery of San Lorenzo de El Escorial

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host after desecration)
description: A consecrated Host trampled and pierced during a church plundering began to bleed and was later preserved intact.
narrative: In 1572, during the religious conflicts in Holland, Protestant mercenaries entered the Catholic church of Gorkum and plundered it. As an act of sacrilege, one of the mercenaries trampled a consecrated Host with a spiked boot, breaking it into three pieces. Immediately, living Blood began to flow from the pierced Hosts, forming three distinct wounds that are still visible today. After the city was evacuated, the Host was recovered and safeguarded by the Catholic faithful. Following several investigations, the miraculous relic was presented to King Philip II of Spain in 1594. He placed it in the Royal Monastery of San Lorenzo de El Escorial, near Madrid, where it has been preserved and venerated ever since. The Host, known as the “Sagrada Forma,” remains intact and is solemnly exposed and carried in procession each year on September 29 and October 28, commemorating the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by eyewitness accounts of the bleeding Host, ecclesiastical verification in Holland, and continuous preservation and veneration of the relic at El Escorial.
significance: The miracle became a powerful testimony to the Real Presence during the Reformation era, strengthened Catholic devotion, and established El Escorial as a major center of Eucharistic veneration.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Guadalupe

location.address: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, Guadalupe (Extremadura)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host and overflowing chalice)
description: During Mass, abundant drops of Blood fell from the consecrated Host, filling and overflowing the chalice and staining the corporal and pall.
narrative: In 1420, while celebrating Holy Mass in the region of Toledo, the Venerable Don Pedro Cabañuelas—known for his deep devotion and long hours of Eucharistic adoration—was severely tempted by doubts about transubstantiation. At the moment of consecration, a dense cloud descended and settled above the altar, preventing him from seeing. As he implored the Lord to remove his doubts, the cloud gradually lifted to reveal the Host elevated above the chalice. Abundant drops of Blood began to fall, immediately filling the chalice and overflowing onto the corporal and the pall. A voice instructed the priest to end the Mass and to reveal the event to no one for the moment. The miracle was later made public by Don Pedro’s brothers and spread throughout Spain, reaching King Juan II of Castile and Queen Maria of Aragon, who became deeply devoted and asked to be buried near Don Pedro. The blood-stained corporal and pall were later exhibited during the Eucharistic Congress of Toledo in 1926 and are still venerated today at the Sanctuary of Guadalupe.
scientificEvidence: Numerous historical documents attest to the event, and the preserved relics—the blood-stained corporal and pall—have been exhibited and venerated publicly, including at the 1926 Eucharistic Congress of Toledo.
significance: The miracle strengthened faith in the Real Presence among clergy and laity, inspired royal devotion, and established Guadalupe as a major center of Eucharistic veneration in Spain.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Ivorra

location.address: Church of San Cugat, Ivorra (Diocese of Urgell)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into Blood)
description: During Mass, the wine in the chalice was entirely transformed into living Blood and flowed onto the altar cloth and the ground.
narrative: In the year 1010, the parish priest of Ivorra, Bernat Oliver, was troubled by doubts concerning the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist, influenced by heretical teachings spreading in Europe at the time. One day, while celebrating Holy Mass, the miracle occurred: the wine contained in the chalice was completely transformed into living Blood and poured out onto the altar cloth, flowing until it reached the ground. Shocked and repentant, the priest informed Saint Ermengol, Bishop of Urgell, who immediately went to Ivorra to investigate. The facts were then reported directly to Pope Sergius IV in Rome. The Pope confirmed the authenticity of the miracle and issued a pontifical bull certifying it as a true Eucharistic miracle. The blood-stained altar cloth and other relics were placed beneath the high altar of the parish church, which was later dedicated to San Cugat and inaugurated in 1055. Over the centuries, devotion to the miracle increased, and to accommodate pilgrims, a new sanctuary was built in 1663. Today, the sacred relics are preserved in a Gothic reliquary from 1426 that contains the blood-stained corporal and additional relics given by Pope Sergius IV to Saint Ermengol. Each year, on the second Sunday of Easter, the faithful celebrate the great feast known as the ‘Santa Duda’ (Holy Doubt), commemorating both the priest’s doubt and the miracle that confirmed the Real Presence.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by episcopal investigation, papal confirmation by Pope Sergius IV, preserved blood-stained relics, and continuous historical documentation and veneration spanning more than a millennium.
significance: One of the earliest recorded Eucharistic miracles in Europe, Ivorra powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence, countered Eucharistic doubt, and established a lasting pilgrimage tradition centered on the ‘Holy Doubt.’

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Moncada

location.address: Parish church of Moncada; Monastery of Santa Inés (Inés of Moncada)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of the Child Jesus in the Host)
description: During Mass, the Child Jesus appeared in the consecrated Host to confirm the validity of a priest’s ordination.
narrative: At the end of the 14th century, during the turmoil of the Western Schism, many clergy doubted the validity of their ordinations because of rival papal obediences. In Moncada, the priest Fr. José Jaime Carros, ordained by a bishop aligned with the Avignon obedience, was deeply troubled by doubts about whether his priestly orders were valid. On December 26, 1392, after fervent prayer, he celebrated Mass and consecrated two Hosts. At that moment, the consecrated Host in his hands became visibly luminous, and the Child Jesus appeared within it. Lady Ángela, present at Mass, saw the Child in the priest’s hands; later, the hermit Saint Inés of Moncada was invited to attend Mass the following day. When Fr. Carros again consecrated the Host, the Child Jesus appeared once more. Asked what she saw, Inés replied, “I see a little white child.” The priest and the congregation were overwhelmed with joy, and the miracle was taken as divine confirmation of the priest’s valid ordination. Although an antipope had ordained the bishop, the Church later recognized that apostolic succession had been preserved through the imposition of hands. The event was recorded by Fr. Odorico Raynaldi in his *Annales Ecclesiastici* and in other documents preserved in the archives of Moncada.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous eyewitness testimony, historical chronicles (including the Annales Ecclesiastici), and sustained ecclesiastical tradition preserved in Moncada’s archives.
significance: The miracle resolved widespread doubts during the Western Schism, reaffirmed confidence in apostolic succession and the Real Presence, and became a defining event in Moncada’s spiritual history.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Montserrat

location.address: Sanctuary and Monastery of Our Lady of Montserrat, Catalonia

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Vision and miraculous sign during Mass)
description: During Mass at Montserrat, a girl witnessed visions of purgatory and a miraculous burning of a cloth placed near the altar during the consecration.
narrative: In 1657, at the Monastery of Our Lady of Montserrat, the Most Reverend Father Don Bernardo de Ontiveros, General of the Benedictine Order in Spain, and Abbot Don Millán de Miranda were present for a series of Masses offered for the soul of a deceased man. A woman and her young daughter begged the Abbot to celebrate three Masses in memory of the girl’s father, believing that these would free him from the pains of purgatory. During the first Mass, the girl reported seeing her father kneeling amid terrifying flames at the steps of the main altar. During the consecration, the priest and the General, filled with doubt, asked the girl to place a piece of cloth near the flames that appeared to surround her father. When she returned the cloth, it was thrown into the fire and immediately began to burn with a lively flame. During the second Mass, the girl confirmed that her father appeared dressed in a radiant-colored suit standing beside the deacon. At the third Mass, her father appeared dressed in snow-white garments, ascended joyfully into the sky, and disappeared. The girl then thanked the priest for the Masses offered for her father’s soul. The event was later recorded by the Benedictine priest R.P. Francio de Paula Crusellas in his work *New History of the Sanctuary and Monastery of Our Lady of Montserrat* and was witnessed by senior clergy and numerous townspeople.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by detailed historical testimony, eyewitness accounts from clergy and laypeople, and written documentation by Benedictine historians preserved in the monastery’s tradition.
significance: The miracle reinforced belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist, emphasized the efficacy of the Holy Mass for the souls in purgatory, and strengthened Montserrat’s role as a major spiritual center in Spain.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of O’Cebreiro

location.address: Church of Santa María la Real, O’Cebreiro, Galicia

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host changed into Flesh and wine into Blood)
description: During Mass, the Host changed into Flesh and the wine into Blood, which overflowed from the chalice and stained the corporal.
narrative: In the icy winter of the year 1300, a Benedictine priest was celebrating Holy Mass in a small chapel at O’Cebreiro. Seeing a poor farmer, Juan Santín Barxam, arrive exhausted after walking through snow and ice, the priest inwardly doubted the value of celebrating Mass for a single peasant and also doubted the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. Immediately after pronouncing the words of consecration, the Host visibly changed into living Flesh, and the wine in the chalice was transformed into Blood and overflowed, staining the corporal. At that moment, it appeared that even the head of the wooden statue of the Virgin Mary bowed in adoration. The miracle was preserved and widely venerated, and the chalice, paten, and blood-stained corporal are still kept near the church where the miracle occurred. Over the centuries, the event was officially recognized by the Church and confirmed by papal bulls, including those of Pope Innocent III (1487) and Pope Alexander VII (1659). O’Cebreiro became an important stop on the Camino de Santiago, and to this day pilgrims come annually to venerate the sacred relics, especially during Corpus Christi and other feast days.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by historical eyewitness testimony, preserved physical relics (chalice, paten, blood-stained corporal), papal bulls confirming the event, and continuous public veneration over seven centuries.
significance: One of the most famous Eucharistic miracles in Europe, O’Cebreiro powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence and became a major center of pilgrimage along the Camino de Santiago.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Onil

location.address: Church of St. James the Apostle, Onil (Alicante)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous preservation of a consecrated Host)
description: A stolen consecrated Host was found intact in a field and has remained completely preserved for nearly two centuries.
narrative: On November 5, 1824, Nicolás Bernabeu, a former altar boy at the parish church of Onil, stole a pyx containing a consecrated Host along with other sacred objects. The theft caused great alarm among the faithful. Civil authorities searched for the pyx, suspecting it might be hidden in the nearby town of Tibi. Days later, a woman from Tibi named Teresa Carbonell discovered the stolen pyx containing the consecrated Host in the middle of a green field known as “La Pedrera.” She immediately returned it to Onil, where she was received with great celebration. The Host was placed back in the parish church of St. James the Apostle. Exactly 119 years later, on November 28, 1943, Don Guillermo Hijarrubia, delegate of the Archbishop of Valencia, officially confirmed the authenticity of the miracle, verifying the complete and extraordinary preservation of the Host. To this day, despite the passage of nearly two centuries, the consecrated Host has remained perfectly intact and is solemnly venerated in the parish church. Each year, the faithful celebrate the Feast of Our Lord ‘Robat’ (Stolen Lord) in remembrance of the miracle and the recovery of the Host.
scientificEvidence: Ecclesiastical verification in 1943 confirmed the complete preservation of the consecrated Host after more than a century, excluding natural causes of decay.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, affirmed belief in the Real Presence, and remains a living testimony through the continued intact preservation of the Host.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Ponferrada

location.address: Arenal Field area; Church of St. Peter and Church of St. Mary, Ponferrada

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous recovery and preservation of consecrated Hosts)
description: Stolen consecrated Hosts were recovered intact after miraculous signs of light, doves, and an unmovable tabernacle revealed their location.
narrative: In 1533, Juan de Benavente, a devout parishioner of Ponferrada, succumbed to greed and stole the tabernacle containing a precious silver ciborium with numerous consecrated Hosts from his own parish church. When he attempted to throw the wooden tabernacle into the Sil River, it became impossibly heavy, preventing him from casting it into the water. He hid the stolen items at home, but during the night continuous flashes of light emanated from the tabernacle, alarming his wife. Fearing discovery, Juan carried the tabernacle to the Arenal Field and threw it into a dense blackberry patch. In the following days, eyewitnesses reported intense flashes of light at night and strange doves hovering over the area by day. During local festivities, crossbowmen failed to strike the doves, and the miller Nogaledo ventured into the brambles, where he discovered the tabernacle and consecrated Hosts, from which the light originated. He immediately alerted the town, church bells rang, and a solemn procession returned the Hosts to the church. Overcome with remorse, Juan confessed his crime. A chapel was built at the place of discovery, and in 1570 the parish priest expanded the shrine and instituted an annual solemn procession on the eighth day after the Feast of Corpus Christi in memory of the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through contemporaneous eyewitness testimony, ecclesiastical records, and the enduring signs reported at the recovery site, including the intact condition of the Hosts and sustained public devotion.
significance: The event deepened Eucharistic devotion in Ponferrada, affirmed belief in the Real Presence, and established a lasting tradition of annual processions and pilgrimage centered on the recovered Hosts.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Saint John of the Abbesses

location.address: Monastery of Saint John of the Abbesses, Catalonia

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous preservation of a Host embedded in a crucifix)
description: A consecrated Host placed inside the forehead of a wooden crucifix in 1251 was found perfectly preserved nearly two centuries later.
narrative: In the Pyrenean region of Catalonia, Count Vifred founded a monastery in 887, around which the village of Sant Joan de les Abadesses soon developed. In 1251, wooden sculptures depicting the deposition of Jesus from the Cross were carved for the monastery church. When the crucifix of Christ was created, the artist intentionally made a circular cavity in the forehead of Jesus, approximately two and a half inches in diameter, with the idea of preserving the Eucharist inside. That same year, a consecrated Host was placed within the cavity, though over time the memory of this act was lost. In 1426, during restoration work on the statues, the cavity in the forehead was rediscovered, sealed with a small silver plaque. Inside, wrapped in a white linen cloth, was the consecrated Host from 1251, found completely intact and uncorrupted. From that moment on, the Host—known as “The Most Holy Mystery of Saint John of the Abbesses”—has been solemnly adored and venerated by pilgrims. The crucifix and the miraculous Host survived the destruction of the Spanish Civil War in 1936 and continue to inspire devotion through their striking realism and enduring preservation.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by the rediscovery in 1426 of a consecrated Host preserved intact for nearly 175 years, documented by ecclesiastical records and continuous veneration.
significance: The miracle affirmed belief in the Real Presence, established Sant Joan de les Abadesses as a pilgrimage site, and remains a powerful witness through the extraordinary long-term preservation of the Host.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Silla

location.address: Church of Our Lady of the Angels, Silla (Valencia)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous preservation of consecrated Hosts)
description: Stolen consecrated Hosts were recovered hidden under a stone and found perfectly preserved without corruption.
narrative: On March 25, 1907, the Feast of the Annunciation, during the celebration of Holy Mass at the church of Our Lady of the Angels in Silla, Spain, the pastor Don Gerardo Gómez noticed that the tabernacle door had been forced open and that the ciborium containing the consecrated Hosts was missing. Two days later, the Sacred Species were discovered in a small garden outside the city, hidden under a stone. The pastor immediately returned the Hosts to the church in a solemn procession. Despite having been exposed to moisture, earth, and the elements, the Hosts were found to be in perfect condition. Years later, when it became evident that the Hosts had remained completely unchanged, the Archbishop of Valencia initiated a canonical investigation. In 1934, recognizing that the Hosts were still exactly as they had been found, the Archbishop officially declared their preservation to be miraculous and ordered the reliquary sealed with wax. Although the archbishop’s residence and documentation were destroyed during later persecutions, the Sacred Hosts themselves survived and continue to be preserved and adored in the church of Our Lady of the Angels. Even today, the faithful can venerate the incorrupt Hosts, which have remained intact for more than a century.
scientificEvidence: Ecclesiastical investigation confirmed the extraordinary preservation of the consecrated Hosts over decades despite exposure to natural elements, excluding normal causes of decay.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region of Valencia, reaffirmed belief in the Real Presence, and remains a living testimony through the continued intact preservation of the Hosts.

name: The Holy Chalice of Valencia (Holy Grail)

location.address: Cathedral of Valencia, Chapel of the Santo Cáliz

date.displayDate: Traditionally 1st century; documented in Valencia since 1437

type: Eucharistic Relic (Holy Chalice of the Last Supper)
description: The chalice venerated in Valencia Cathedral is traditionally identified as the cup used by Jesus at the Last Supper to consecrate the Eucharistic wine.
narrative: The Holy Chalice of Valencia—often identified with the Holy Grail—is the cup traditionally believed to have been used by Jesus at the Last Supper to consecrate the Eucharistic wine. Early testimonies report that the chalice was venerated by Christian pilgrims in Jerusalem centuries after Christ; the pilgrim-bishop Arculf (c. 720) describes the chalice preserved in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, while the Venerable Bede notes it was protected by a net and could be kissed through an opening. Though the precise moment of its departure from Jerusalem is unknown, tradition suggests an early transfer, possibly as early as the seventh century. By the fifteenth century the chalice was received and formally documented in Valencia (1437). Today it is kept in the Gothic Chapel of the Santo Cáliz in Valencia Cathedral and is shown for the veneration of the faithful. The object is composed of distinct elements from different periods: an ancient upper cup of cornelian, a stem adorned with precious stones, and a base formed from an inverted cornelian vessel. The upper cup is considered the oldest and most significant component. The Holy Chalice has been publicly venerated by popes, including Saint John Paul II, and remains a focal point of Eucharistic devotion.
scientificEvidence: Historical testimonies (Arculf, Bede), documentary records of custody and transfer, material analysis indicating components from different eras, and continuous ecclesiastical veneration support the tradition surrounding the chalice.
significance: As a revered Eucharistic relic identified by tradition with the cup of the Last Supper, the Holy Chalice of Valencia occupies a central place in Christian devotion to the Eucharist and the history of the Holy Grail tradition.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Zaragoza

location.address: Cathedral of the See (La Seo), Chapel of San Dominguito del Val, Zaragoza

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of the Child Jesus in the Host)
description: A consecrated Host stolen for a superstition manifested as the Baby Jesus, unharmed by fire, and later returned to the Eucharistic species during Mass.
narrative: In 1427, in Zaragoza, a married woman sought a Moorish sorcerer to obtain a charm to soften her husband’s violent behavior. The sorcerer demanded a consecrated Host. The woman went to the church of Saint Michael, confessed, received Holy Communion, and deceitfully removed the Host from her mouth, hiding it in a small coffer. When the coffer was opened, instead of the Host there appeared a little Baby surrounded by light. Terrified, the sorcerer instructed her to burn the Eucharist and bring him the ashes. The woman burned the coffer, but though it was completely consumed, the Baby remained unharmed. Stricken with fear, both went to inform Bishop Don Alonso Arhuello, confessing their sin and seeking baptism. After consulting prelates and theologians, the bishop ordered a solemn procession carrying the Miraculous Baby from the woman’s house to the cathedral. The entire city accompanied the procession. The Baby was placed on the altar of the chapel of Saint Valerio so the faithful could venerate Him. The following day, while the bishop celebrated Mass at the same altar, at the words of consecration the Baby disappeared and a Host appeared in His place, which the bishop immediately consumed. Documents describing the miracle are preserved in the town hall archives, and an ancient painting near the chapel of San Dominguito del Val in the Cathedral of the See depicts the event.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented by a contemporaneous written report by the archdeacon Don Dorner, episcopal inquiry, preserved civic records, and enduring iconographic evidence within the cathedral.
significance: The miracle renewed Eucharistic devotion in Zaragoza, led to citywide veneration, and remains commemorated through archival documentation and sacred art affirming belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Alatri

location.address: Cathedral of Saint Paul the Apostle, Alatri (Lazio)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into bleeding Flesh)
description: A consecrated Host stolen during Mass was later found transformed into bleeding flesh.
narrative: In 1228, in the city of Alatri, a young woman seeking to regain the affection of her sweetheart consulted a sorceress, who instructed her to steal a consecrated Host in order to prepare a love potion. During Holy Mass, the woman deceitfully retained the Host in her mouth and later concealed it in a cloth. After three days, upon opening the cloth at home, she discovered that the Host had been transformed into bleeding flesh. Stricken with fear and remorse, both the young woman and the sorceress confessed the sacrilege to Bishop Giovanni V of Alatri. The event was carefully investigated and officially reported to Pope Gregory IX, who responded with the papal bull *Fraternitas tuae* dated March 13, 1228. In this document, the Pope affirmed the miracle as a divine sign strengthening faith in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist, particularly against contemporary heresies. The Pope ordered a merciful penance for the repentant young woman and left the discipline of the sorceress to episcopal judgment. The miraculous fragment of flesh has since been preserved in a reliquary and is still venerated today in the Cathedral of Saint Paul the Apostle. Paintings illustrating the miracle, commemorative medals, and extensive documentation continue to testify to the event.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by extensive ecclesiastical documentation, including the papal bull *Fraternitas tuae* of Pope Gregory IX, episcopal records, preserved relics, and continuous public veneration.
significance: One of the most thoroughly documented medieval Eucharistic miracles, Alatri played a major role in reaffirming Catholic doctrine on the Real Presence and countering Eucharistic heresies of the 13th century.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Saint Clare of Assisi

location.address: Convent of San Damiano, Assisi (Umbria)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Blessed Sacrament repels invading army)
description: Saint Clare drove away Saracen invaders by exposing the Blessed Sacrament, trusting in Christ’s Real Presence for protection.
narrative: In September 1240, during an assault on Assisi by Saracen mercenaries in the service of Emperor Frederick II, enemy soldiers breached the walls of the Convent of San Damiano and entered the cloister of the Poor Clares. The sisters, terrified, fled to their abbess, Saint Clare, who was gravely ill at the time. With fearless faith, Clare ordered herself to be carried to the entrance of the monastery with the Blessed Sacrament enclosed in a precious silver and ivory monstrance. Prostrating herself before the Eucharist, she tearfully implored Christ not to abandon His defenseless handmaids. From the tabernacle, a voice like that of a child responded, promising perpetual protection. Clare then prayed also for the city of Assisi, and Christ replied that although the city would face trials, it would be defended by His protection. Rising, Clare reassured the sisters that no harm would come to them if they trusted in Christ. At the sight of Clare holding the Eucharist, the Saracen soldiers were seized with terror and fled back over the walls they had climbed. Saint Clare later commanded the sisters not to reveal the heavenly voice during her lifetime. The miracle is recorded in *The History of Saint Clare, Virgin* by Tommaso da Celano and has been commemorated in sacred art and tradition ever since.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by early hagiographical testimony from Tommaso da Celano, eyewitness monastic tradition, and continuous historical and artistic documentation.
significance: This miracle powerfully affirms belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist and highlights the Eucharist as a source of divine protection for the Church and society.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Asti (1535)

location.address: Collegiate Church of San Secondo, Asti (Piedmont)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host)
description: During Mass, a consecrated Host visibly exuded living Blood along its fracture and into the chalice.
narrative: On July 25, 1535, around seven o’clock in the morning, Father Domenico Occelli was celebrating Holy Mass at the main altar of the collegiate church of San Secondo in Asti. At the breaking of the consecrated Host, he noticed that the entire fracture line had become red with living Blood. Three drops fell into the chalice, while a fourth remained at the edge of the Host. When he attempted to place a portion of the Host into the chalice, more Blood flowed out. Overcome with amazement, the priest invited the faithful to approach the altar and witness the miracle. When he finally consumed the Host, the Blood disappeared and the Host returned to its normal appearance. Bishop Scipione Roero had an official notarial act drawn up and sent a report to the Holy See. On November 6, 1535, Pope Paul III issued an Apostolic Brief granting a plenary indulgence to those who visited the Church of San Secondo on the anniversary of the miracle. Contemporary documents also report the conversion of heretical soldiers stationed in Asti at the time under Emperor Charles V.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by a notarized episcopal report, papal documentation (Apostolic Brief of Pope Paul III), eyewitness testimony, archival records, and artistic depictions preserved in the church.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic faith in Asti during a time of religious conflict and remains one of the most historically documented Eucharistic miracles of the 16th century.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Asti (1718)

location.address: Opera Pia Milliavacca; Cathedral of Asti

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host and Chalice)
description: During Mass, a consecrated Host appeared divided and stained with real blood, which also marked the chalice and corporal.
narrative: On the morning of May 10, 1718, Father Francesco Scotto celebrated Holy Mass in the chapel of the Opera Pia Milliavacca in Asti. During the elevation, the notary public Scipione Alessandro Ambrogio noticed that the consecrated Host appeared divided into two parts. Believing a broken Host to be invalid, he rushed to obtain another consecrated Host. Meanwhile, the priest elevated the Host and found both parts stained with Blood. Blood was also visible at the bottom of the chalice and on the corporal. When Ambrogio returned, he immediately recognized the miracle and burst into tears. Several clerics, theologians, physicians, and surgeons were summoned. Doctors Argenta, Volpini, and Vercellone formally attested that the stains were real blood, excluding natural causes such as injury to the priest. A notarial report was drawn up, and the miracle was widely attested. In 1841, Bishop Filippo Artico ordered a renewed examination of the chalice and Host, confirming again the blood stains. The chalice of the miracle is preserved today in the Cathedral of Asti, in the chapel dedicated to Saint Philip Neri.
scientificEvidence: The miracle was examined by physicians, surgeons, theologians, and notarial authorities in 1718, with further episcopal verification in 1841 confirming the blood stains.
significance: This second miracle reinforced belief in the Real Presence and stands as one of the most medically examined Eucharistic miracles of the early modern period.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bagno di Romagna

location.address: Basilica of Santa Maria Assunta, Bagno di Romagna (Emilia-Romagna)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Consecrated wine transformed into living Blood)
description: During Mass, the consecrated wine was transformed into living Blood that flowed from the chalice and soaked the corporal.
narrative: In 1412, Fr. Lazzaro da Verona, then prior of the Basilica of Santa Maria in Bagno di Romagna, was celebrating Holy Mass when he was assailed by doubts about the Real Presence of Jesus in the Most Holy Sacrament. Immediately after pronouncing the words of consecration over the wine, it was transformed into living Blood, which flowed from the chalice and fell onto the corporal, soaking it. Profoundly moved and repentant, Fr. Lazzaro turned to the faithful present, confessed his unbelief, and proclaimed the miracle God had worked before their eyes. The historian Fortunio records the event in his Annales Camaldulenses, describing the priest’s intense emotion and the corporal remaining soaked with Blood. The blood-stained corporal has been preserved in the Basilica of Santa Maria Assunta and has been venerated for centuries. Fr. Lazzaro was later transferred to Bologna, where he died in 1416. In 1912, the fifth centenary of the miracle was solemnly celebrated, and in 1958 a chemical analysis conducted at the University of Florence confirmed that the stains on the corporal were of hematological nature. Each year, especially during the Feast of Corpus Christi, the corporal is carried in procession through the streets of Bagno di Romagna and regularly exposed for veneration.
scientificEvidence: A chemical analysis performed in 1958 at the University of Florence confirmed the blood stains on the corporal to be of hematological origin; extensive historical documentation and continuous veneration support the miracle.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the Camaldolese tradition and remains a powerful witness to belief in the Real Presence through the preserved blood-stained corporal.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Bolsena

location.address: Church of Saint Christina of Bolsena; Orvieto Cathedral (relics)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host)
description: During Mass, a consecrated Host bled onto the corporal, confirming the Real Presence to a doubting priest.

Though devout, he struggled to believe fully in the Real Presence. At the moment of consecration, Blood began to seep from the Host, staining his hands and the altar linen. Shocked, he attempted to conceal the Blood, then interrupted the Mass and sought Pope Urban IV in nearby Orvieto. After investigation, the Pope ordered the Host and the blood-stained corporal brought to him; the relics were enshrined in Orvieto Cathedral, where the corporal remains on display. The miracle was examined by Church authorities, including St. Thomas Aquinas. Moved by this sign, Pope Urban IV commissioned Aquinas to compose the liturgical texts for the feast of the Most Holy Body of the Lord and, in August 1264, instituted the Feast of Corpus Christi for the universal Church by papal bull. The event is famously depicted in Renaissance art, including Raphael’s fresco in the Vatican.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous ecclesiastical investigation, papal action, preserved blood-stained linens, and extensive documentary and artistic testimony.
significance: Bolsena directly led to the universal establishment of the Feast of Corpus Christi and stands as one of the most influential Eucharistic miracles in Church history.
