name: Eucharistic Miracle of Canosio

location.address: Parish Church of Canosio, Val Maira (Diocese of Saluzzo)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Blessed Sacrament halts floodwaters)
description: A devastating flood was stopped when the parish priest blessed the raging waters with the Blessed Sacrament.
narrative: Canosio is a small village in the Val Maira, within the Diocese of Saluzzo. In 1630, many townspeople had grown spiritually indifferent due to the spread of Calvinist ideas. On the day after the Feast of Corpus Christi, torrential rains caused the Maira River to overflow violently. The floodwaters dislodged massive stones from the mountains and threatened to destroy the valley and the village itself. Father Antonio Reinardi, the parish priest, gathered the people to the ringing of church bells and urged them to pray fervently. He made a solemn vow that if the Lord spared Canosio from destruction, the people would celebrate an annual feast in perpetuity. Taking the Blessed Sacrament, Father Reinardi placed it in a monstrance and processed toward the raging river, accompanied by the faithful chanting Psalm 51. As he blessed the waters with the Eucharist, the flood suddenly stopped, receded at once, and the river returned to its normal level. The village was saved. The miracle led to numerous conversions among the witnesses, renewed faith in the Eucharist, and to this day the people of Canosio commemorate the event with a feast celebrated during the Octave of Corpus Christi.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by eyewitness testimony, local historical documentation preserved in later copies, and continuous liturgical commemoration maintained by the parish.
significance: The miracle restored Eucharistic faith in a time of religious crisis, strengthened devotion to the Real Presence, and established a perpetual vow and feast that continues to unite the community of Canosio.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Cascia

location.address: Basilica of Saint Rita of Cascia; Church of Saint Augustine, Cascia (Umbria)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Blood)
description: A consecrated Host irreverently placed in a prayer book was transformed into Blood, staining the pages.
narrative: In 1330, at Cascia, a gravely ill peasant asked a priest to bring him Holy Communion. Through carelessness and apathy, the priest failed to carry the ciborium and instead placed a consecrated Host irreverently between the pages of his prayer book. Upon arriving at the sick man’s home, the priest opened the book and was astonished to find that the Host had been transformed into a clot of living Blood and that the pages of the book were stained with Blood. Shocked and repentant, the priest confessed his negligence. The miracle was reported to ecclesiastical authorities and carefully examined. The blood-stained pages and the relic of the miracle were preserved and later placed in a precious monstrance. Over the centuries, the miracle of Cascia became an important focus of Eucharistic devotion. It is commemorated in sacred art, and indulgences were granted to the faithful who venerated the relics. The relics are preserved in Cascia, near the Basilica dedicated to Saint Rita, and continue to be an object of devotion and pilgrimage.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by ecclesiastical documentation, preserved blood-stained relics, continuous public veneration, and historical accounts recorded in the local and monastic tradition.
significance: The miracle reaffirmed belief in the Real Presence and served as a powerful reminder of reverence due to the Eucharist, becoming a lasting source of devotion in Cascia.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Cava dei Tirreni

location.address: Castle of the Annunciation (Castello di Sant’Adiutore) and Monte Castello, Cava dei Tirreni (Campania)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Plague halted by Corpus Christi procession)
description: A deadly plague epidemic ceased after a Corpus Christi procession and blessing with the Blessed Sacrament on Monte Castello.
narrative: In May 1656, a devastating plague epidemic struck southern Italy, spreading from Naples into neighboring towns and countryside. Thousands died, and by May 25—the feast of the Ascension—the plague had reached the gates of Cava dei Tirreni. Fr. Paolo Franco, one of the few priests spared by the epidemic, felt divinely inspired to lead the population in a penitential Corpus Christi procession. Carrying the Blessed Sacrament, he led the faithful from the Castle of the Annunciation up toward the higher terrace of Monte Castello. Upon reaching the summit, Fr. Franco solemnly blessed the city of Cava dei Tirreni with the Eucharist. Immediately thereafter, the plague miraculously ceased, sparing the city from further devastation. In gratitude, the people of Cava vowed perpetual remembrance of the miracle. Since 1657, the event has been commemorated annually through a solemn procession and celebration known as the “Feast of the Castello” or “Sagra di Montecastello,” which continues to unite the community in Eucharistic devotion.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by historical records, civic and ecclesiastical tradition, eyewitness testimony preserved in later accounts, and uninterrupted annual commemoration since the 17th century.
significance: The miracle strengthened faith in the protective power of the Eucharist during times of crisis and remains a defining spiritual and cultural event in the life of Cava dei Tirreni.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Dronero

location.address: Church of St. Brigid, Dronero (Piedmont)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Fire extinguished by the Blessed Sacrament)
description: A raging fire threatening the town of Dronero was miraculously extinguished when the Blessed Sacrament was brought in procession.
narrative: On the afternoon of Sunday, August 3, 1631, a young farm girl accidentally ignited a fire while lighting dry hay. Because of a strong wind, the flames rapidly spread through the Borgo Marina district of Dronero, and every attempt to extinguish the fire proved useless. As panic spread among the townspeople, a Capuchin friar, Maurice da Ceva, inspired by deep faith in the power of the Eucharist, resolved to invoke divine help. He organized a solemn procession and took the monstrance containing the Blessed Sacrament from the Church of St. Brigid. Walking directly toward the raging fire, he blessed the flames with the Eucharist. At the very moment the Blessed Sacrament arrived, the fire suddenly subsided and was completely extinguished, saving the town from destruction. The miraculous event was recorded on a stone tablet placed in the Church of St. Brigid. In gratitude, the citizens of Dronero established a solemn annual procession with the Blessed Sacrament, celebrated on the Feast of Corpus Christi, to perpetually commemorate the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is attested by contemporary civic and ecclesiastical testimony, a commemorative stone tablet, and continuous annual liturgical observance maintained by the town.
significance: The miracle reinforced faith in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist and remains a defining act of communal devotion and gratitude in Dronero.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of San Mauro la Bruca

location.address: Parish Church of San Mauro la Bruca, Province of Salerno (Campania)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous preservation of consecrated Hosts)
description: Consecrated Hosts stolen and discarded by thieves were found intact and preserved without corruption.
narrative: On the night of July 25, 1969, unknown thieves broke into the parish church of San Mauro la Bruca with the intention of stealing precious objects. After forcing open the tabernacle, they took the pyx containing many consecrated Hosts. Realizing they could not profit from them, the thieves emptied the ciborium and threw the Hosts onto a footpath at a nearby intersection. The following morning, a child noticed the Hosts scattered on the road and reverently gathered them, immediately informing the parish priest. The Hosts were carefully recovered and placed back in the church. On the same day, July 25, 1969, Bishop Giuseppe D’Agostino of the Diocese of Vallo della Lucania officially recognized the extraordinary preservation of the Hosts and authorized their public veneration. Scientific observation confirmed that while unconsecrated hosts normally deteriorate after several months, these Hosts remained intact and unchanged over time. Today, the consecrated Hosts are preserved and exposed for adoration in the parish church of San Mauro la Bruca, continuing to inspire Eucharistic devotion among the faithful.
scientificEvidence: Observation over time showed the consecrated Hosts remained intact while ordinary hosts would normally decay, leading ecclesiastical authority to exclude natural causes.
significance: The miracle reaffirmed faith in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist and continues to serve as a modern witness to Eucharistic devotion in southern Italy.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Ferrara

location.address: Basilica of Santa Maria in Vado, Ferrara (Emilia-Romagna)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host)
description: During Easter Mass, blood gushed from the consecrated Host and splattered the ceiling vault above the altar.
narrative: On Easter Sunday, March 28, 1171, Father Pietro da Verona, prior of the Canons Regular Portuensi, was celebrating Mass in the Basilica of Santa Maria in Vado in Ferrara, assisted by three confreres. At the moment of the breaking of the consecrated Host, a sudden gush of Blood sprang forth, striking the ceiling vault above the altar with large droplets. Witnesses described the holy terror of the celebrant and the immense astonishment of the faithful who crowded the small church. Several testified that the Host appeared blood-red and that within it they saw the figure of a Child. Bishop Amato of Ferrara and Archbishop Gherardo of Ravenna were immediately informed and personally verified the Blood staining the vault. The church became an immediate destination for pilgrims and was later rebuilt and enlarged under Duke Ercole d’Este beginning in 1495. In 1595, the blood-stained vault was enclosed within a shrine, which remains visible today. Numerous historical sources attest to the miracle, including a manuscript of Gerardo Cambrense (1197) preserved in Canterbury, the Bull of Pope Eugene IV (1442), and the Bull of Cardinal Migliorati (1404) granting indulgences to those who adored the Miraculous Blood. To this day, Eucharistic Adoration is held monthly on the 28th, and annual devotions continue in preparation for Corpus Christi.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by immediate episcopal eyewitness verification, preserved physical evidence (blood-stained ceiling vault), papal bulls, medieval manuscripts, and uninterrupted liturgical commemoration.
significance: Ferrara stands as one of the most visually preserved Eucharistic miracles in history, with physical evidence still visible, reinforcing belief in the Real Presence for over eight centuries.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Florence (1595)

location.address: Church of Saint Ambrose, Florence (Tuscany)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Hosts preserved unharmed in a church fire)
description: Fragments of consecrated Hosts remained completely intact after a destructive church fire.
narrative: On Good Friday in 1595, a severe fire broke out in a chapel of the Church of Saint Ambrose in Florence, known as the Chapel of the Sepulcher. The flames caused significant destruction and threatened the altar and sacred furnishings. During the chaos, six fragments of consecrated Hosts fell from the pyx onto the smoldering carpet. Despite prolonged exposure to intense heat and fire, the Host fragments were found completely intact and unburned. In 1628, Archbishop Marzio Medici of Florence ordered a formal examination of the relics and confirmed their incorrupt condition. The miraculous Host fragments were placed in a precious reliquary. Each year in May, during the Forty Hours devotion, the two Florentine Eucharistic relics—the Miraculous Blood of 1230 and the Hosts of 1595—are solemnly exposed together for public adoration, continuing a tradition of Eucharistic devotion that has endured for centuries.
scientificEvidence: Ecclesiastical investigation confirmed the Host fragments were unharmed by fire, excluding natural explanations; the relics have been preserved and venerated continuously.
significance: The miracle reaffirmed the sacredness and indestructibility of the Eucharist and strengthened Eucharistic devotion in Florence during the post-Tridentine era.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Gruaro

location.address: Church of St. Giusto, Gruaro; Church of the Most Holy Body of Christ, Valvasone (Friuli-Venezia Giulia)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host)
description: While washing altar linens, a woman discovered a consecrated Particle that began to bleed, staining the cloth.
narrative: In 1294, a young housemaid went to the public wash-house of Versiola to wash the altar linens of the Church of St. Giusto in Gruaro. While washing the cloths, she suddenly noticed that a consecrated Host had remained among the folds of the linen and that Blood was flowing from it, staining the altar cloth. Terrified by the inexplicable event, she immediately alerted the parish priest, who informed Bishop Giacomo di Ottonello of Concordia. The Bishop requested that the miraculous cloth be kept in his cathedral, but the pastor of Gruaro and the Counts of Valvasone, patrons of the local churches, also claimed custody. Unable to reach agreement, the matter was referred to the Holy See. In 1454, Pope Nicholas V issued a decree allowing the Counts of Valvasone to retain the relic on the condition that a church be built in honor of the Most Holy Body of Christ. The construction of the church was completed in 1483. The blood-stained linen is preserved today in a crystal cylinder within a precious silver reliquary crafted by Antonio Calligari and is kept in the Church of the Most Holy Body of Christ in Valvasone. The miracle is commemorated annually on the fifth Thursday of Lent and during Corpus Christi, when the reliquary is carried in solemn procession.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by episcopal investigation, a papal decree by Pope Nicholas V (1454), preserved blood-stained relics, historical documentation, and uninterrupted liturgical commemoration.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region, led to the construction of a major shrine, and remains a powerful medieval witness to belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Macerata

location.address: Cathedral of the Holy Mary Assumed and St. Giuliano, Macerata (Marche)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Bleeding Host)
description: During Mass, a consecrated Host began to bleed, staining the corporal and the chalice on the altar.
narrative: On April 25, 1356, in Macerata, an unnamed priest was celebrating Holy Mass in the chapel of the Church of Saint Catherine, owned by the Benedictine monks. During the breaking of the Host, before Communion, the priest was seized by doubt regarding the Real Presence of Jesus in the Eucharist. At the precise moment he broke the Host, an abundance of Blood flowed from it, staining part of the altar cloth and the chalice on the altar. The priest immediately informed the authorities. The blood-stained corporal was preserved and later transferred to the Cathedral of the Holy Mary Assumed and Saint Giuliano, where it remains today. Historical sources, including the account of the historian Ferdinando Ughelli (1647), record that the corporal was carried in solemn procession through the city and enclosed in an urn of crystal and silver with the participation of the people of the Piceno. Bishop Nicholas of San Martino ordered the relic to be brought into the cathedral and instituted a regular annual procession. In 1439, one of the first confraternities in honor of the Most Blessed Sacrament was founded in Macerata. To this day, each year on the occasion of Corpus Christi, the corporal of the miracle is carried in solemn procession behind the Blessed Sacrament.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous historical documentation, episcopal recognition, preserved blood-stained relics, and continuous liturgical commemoration.
significance: The miracle reaffirmed faith in the Real Presence, strengthened Eucharistic devotion in Macerata, and established enduring traditions of confraternities and Corpus Christi processions.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Mogoro

location.address: Parish of Saint Bernard, Mogoro (Sardinia)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Imprints of consecrated Hosts on stone)
description: After two men in mortal sin spat out consecrated Hosts, their forms were miraculously imprinted on the stone floor and could not be erased.
narrative: In April 1604, on the Monday after Easter, Father Salvatore Spiga, pastor of the Parish of Saint Bernard in Mogoro, was distributing Holy Communion when two men known for their dissolute lives received the Eucharist and immediately spat the Hosts onto the stone floor below the altar rail. They claimed the Hosts had become as hot as burning embers and scorched their tongues, and they fled in remorse for not having gone to Confession. When Father Spiga went to recover the Sacred Hosts, he discovered that clear imprints of the two Hosts had remained on the stone as if sculpted into it. He ordered the stone to be thoroughly washed, but every attempt failed. The event was investigated by Bishop Antonio Surredo and later described by historians including Pietro M. Cossu and Father Casu. Among the most important confirming documents is a public notarial act dated May 25, 1686, drawn up by notary Pedro Antonio Escano, stipulating the construction of a wooden tabernacle over the main altar with an opening to display the “stone of the miracle” so the faithful could venerate it. The stone still bears the imprints today. In reparation for the sacrilege, Mogoro has observed a solemn Eucharistic procession every year on the Sunday after Easter.
scientificEvidence: Contemporaneous episcopal investigations, multiple historical attestations, and the enduring, unerasable imprints preserved in situ support the miracle.
significance: The miracle renewed Eucharistic devotion in Mogoro and established a lasting public act of reparation through annual processions centered on the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Morrovalle

location.address: Former Franciscan Church and Convent, Morrovalle (Marche)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host preserved from fire)
description: A large consecrated Host remained completely intact after a devastating fire destroyed the Franciscan church.
narrative: At about two o’clock in the morning on April 17, 1560, a violent fire broke out in the Franciscan church of Morrovalle. Brother Angelo Blasi, awakened by the crackling of flames, discovered that the church was engulfed in fire and immediately alerted the other friars. Despite the destruction of the building, the pyx containing a large consecrated Host was later found inside a wall cavity near the main altar. The pyx itself had been completely burned except for the lid, yet the Host inside was perfectly preserved and unchanged. Father Battista d’Ascoli, who discovered the Host while clearing debris, was deeply moved, and the news quickly spread among the faithful. For three consecutive days, the Blessed Sacrament was exposed for public adoration. Franciscan Provincial Father Evangelista da Morro d’Alba placed the miraculous Host in a glass ciborium. Pope Pius IV ordered an official investigation, and once natural causes were excluded, he authorized public devotion. In 1560, the Pope issued the Bull “Holy Roman Church,” granting indulgences to those who visited the site on the anniversary of the miracle. The Host has been preserved to this day in the Church of Saint Bartholomew. In 1960, on the fourth centenary of the miracle, the City Council unanimously decided to place the inscription “Civitas Eucharistica” on the main gate of Morrovalle, affirming the town’s enduring Eucharistic identity.
scientificEvidence: Ecclesiastical investigation ordered by Pope Pius IV excluded natural explanations; the intact Host and partially burned pyx were preserved as physical evidence.
significance: The miracle established Morrovalle as a city publicly dedicated to Eucharistic devotion and remains a lasting testimony to belief in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Offida

location.address: Church of Saint Augustine, Offida (Marche)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into living Flesh)
description: A consecrated Host, taken for sacrilegious purposes, was transformed into living Flesh and later solemnly venerated.
narrative: Between 1273 and 1280 in Offida, near the Church of Saint Augustine, a woman named Richiarella sought the help of a witch to regain her husband’s affection. Following the witch’s instructions, she received Holy Communion and secretly brought the consecrated Host home. Intending to reduce it to powder, she placed it in an earthenware jar over the fire. Instead, the Host was transformed into living Flesh. Terrified, Richiarella wrapped the jar and the bloodied Host in a linen cloth and buried it beneath manure in her husband’s stable. Extraordinary signs soon followed: each time the donkey entered the stable, it knelt toward the spot where the Host was buried. Years later, overcome by remorse, Richiarella confessed her sacrilege to Giacomo Diotallevi, prior of the Augustinian priory in Lanciano and a native of Offida, crying, “I killed God! I killed God!” The priest recovered the relics and brought them to Offida, where they were entrusted to the faithful. A cross-shaped reliquary was crafted by a Venetian artisan to house the miraculous Host. Numerous papal decrees—from Boniface VIII in 1295 to Sixtus V in 1585—along with episcopal acts, communal statutes, votive offerings, frescoes, and historical testimonies authenticated and promoted devotion to the miracle. The reliquaries containing the Host, the blood-stained linen, and the oil jar are preserved and exposed in the Church of Saint Augustine. Each year on May 3, the citizens of Offida solemnly celebrate the anniversary of the miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by medieval documentation, an authenticated 13th-century parchment copy, papal decrees, episcopal investigations, preserved relics, and uninterrupted public veneration.
significance: The miracle of Offida reinforced belief in the Real Presence, inspired centuries of Eucharistic devotion, and remains one of the most thoroughly documented medieval Eucharistic miracles in Italy.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Patierno

location.address: Church of St. Peter, Patierno (Naples, Campania)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous preservation of consecrated Hosts)
description: Consecrated Hosts stolen from the Church of St. Peter were later found preserved in an unexplained manner.
narrative: On February 24, 1772, unknown thieves stole a number of consecrated Hosts from the Church of St. Peter in Patierno, near Naples. The Hosts were later discovered intact and preserved in a manner that could not be explained by natural causes. An archdiocesan investigation was opened and lasted two years, concluding in 1774 with a favorable judgment recognizing the miraculous preservation. Testimonies collected during the trial affirmed that the condition of the Hosts surpassed what could be accounted for by physical laws. Among later confirmations, renowned scientists of the time—identified in the documentation as Domenico Cotugno of the Royal University of Naples and Professor Pietro De Francisci, a teacher of human physiology—attested that the phenomenon could not be explained by natural agents. In 1967, Cardinal Corrado Ursi elevated the Church of St. Peter to a diocesan Eucharistic sanctuary. In 1971, a diocesan Eucharistic Year was established to help the faithful deepen their understanding of the miracle. Sadly, in 1978, unknown thieves stole the relics of the miraculous Hosts. Despite this loss, the event remains an enduring witness to Eucharistic faith in Patierno.
scientificEvidence: Archdiocesan trial records (1772–1774) excluded natural causes; later scientific testimonies affirmed the unexplained preservation of the Hosts.
significance: The miracle strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the Diocese of Naples, led to official ecclesiastical recognition, and inspired diocesan initiatives centered on the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Rimini

location.address: Temple of the Most Holy Eucharist (site of the miracle), Rimini (Emilia-Romagna)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Adoration of the Eucharist by an animal)
description: A mule, after days of fasting, knelt before the consecrated Host and refused food, affirming the Real Presence.
narrative: In 1227 at Rimini, Saint Anthony of Padua was challenged by a Catharist heretic named Bonovillo to prove the truth of the Real Presence of Jesus in the Eucharist. Bonovillo proposed that his mule be kept without food for three days and then publicly offered both fodder and the consecrated Host; if the animal adored the Eucharist rather than eating, he would convert. Saint Anthony accepted the challenge. At the appointed time, in the Grand Piazza of Rimini (today the Piazza Tre Martiri), the saint stood holding the consecrated Host in a monstrance while Bonovillo presented food to the starving mule. At Saint Anthony’s command, spoken in the name of the Creator, the mule ignored the fodder, approached the Host, knelt on its front legs, and remained reverently before it. True to his word, Bonovillo publicly renounced his heresy and converted to the Catholic faith, later becoming a zealous collaborator of Saint Anthony. The miracle is recorded in some of the earliest sources on Saint Anthony’s life, including “L’Assidua” and “Begninitas,” and a church was later built in Rimini in honor of this Eucharistic miracle.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by early biographical sources of Saint Anthony, eyewitness testimony preserved in medieval hagiography, and continuous ecclesiastical tradition.
significance: The miracle powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence, led to the conversion of heretics, and remains one of the most famous Eucharistic miracles associated with Saint Anthony of Padua.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Rome (Mass of St. Gregory the Great)

location.address: Ancient church dedicated to Saint Peter, Rome; relic preserved at the Benedictine Monastery of Andechs, Germany

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Flesh and Blood)
description: During Mass celebrated by Pope St. Gregory the Great, the consecrated Bread turned into Flesh and Blood before a doubting communicant.
narrative: In A.D. 595 in Rome, Pope St. Gregory the Great was celebrating Holy Mass in an ancient church dedicated to Saint Peter. At that time, it was customary for parishioners to prepare the Eucharistic bread themselves. Among those approaching Holy Communion was a Roman noblewoman who had prepared some of the bread and who began laughing as she approached the Pope. When questioned, she admitted that she doubted the Real Presence, finding it impossible that bread she had made with her own hands could become the Body and Blood of Christ. Troubled by her disbelief, Pope Gregory denied her Communion and prayed fervently that God would enlighten her. Having finished praying, the Pope saw that part of the consecrated Bread prepared by the woman was transformed into Flesh and Blood. The woman immediately repented, fell to her knees, and wept. Pope St. Gregory himself was a direct eyewitness to the prodigy. The miracle is recorded in early sources, including *Vita Beati Gregorii Papae* written by Deacon Paul in 787. A relic of the miraculous Host has been preserved through the centuries and is housed today in the Benedictine Monastery of Andechs, near Munich, Germany.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by early written sources, direct papal eyewitness testimony, and the long-term preservation of the relic in a Benedictine monastery.
significance: This miracle powerfully affirmed belief in the Real Presence during the early centuries of the Church and is one of the most important Eucharistic miracles associated with a reigning Pope.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Rome (Santa Pudenziana)

location.address: Church of Santa Pudenziana, Caetani Chapel, Rome

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Miraculous imprint and blood stain of a fallen Host)
description: A consecrated Host that fell during Mass left a visible imprint and blood stain on the altar step, still preserved today.
narrative: In 1610, while a priest was celebrating Holy Mass in the Caetani Chapel of the Church of Santa Pudenziana in Rome, he was overtaken by doubts about the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. Immediately after the consecration, the Host slipped from his hands and fell onto the marble step of the altar. At that moment, the Host left a clear imprint and a stain of Blood on the stone. The mark could not be removed and remains visible to this day. Santa Pudenziana is among the oldest churches in Rome, traditionally associated with Senator Pudente, who is said to have hosted the Apostle Peter in his home on the same site. The church, constructed in A.D. 145 and adorned with early Christian mosaics, preserves the miraculous altar step in the Caetani Chapel as a lasting witness to the Real Presence. The faithful continue to venerate the imprint and blood stain, which serve as a perpetual reminder of reverence due to the Eucharist.
scientificEvidence: The enduring, unremovable imprint and blood stain on the marble altar step have been preserved for centuries and are documented by historical records and direct visual inspection.
significance: The miracle underscores the reality of Christ’s presence in the Eucharist and remains a visible sign of faith within one of Rome’s most ancient churches.

name: Miracle of the Sacred Heart Statue of Rosano

location.address: Abbey of Santa Maria of Rosano, Monastery Church, Rosano (Tuscany)

type: Extraordinary Phenomenon (Statue wept and bled)
description: A life-sized statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus repeatedly wept and shed blood in the monastery church of Rosano.
narrative: In 1948, a life-sized statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus was donated to the Abbey of Santa Maria of Rosano in fulfillment of a vow made during World War II. On April 4, 1948—the first Sunday after Easter—during the chanting of Vespers, drops resembling blood were seen falling from the eyes of the statue. In June of the same year, an even more striking phenomenon occurred when blood flowed visibly from the statue. These events were repeated on various occasions between 1948 and 1950 and were witnessed by the Benedictine nuns of the abbey, including the abbess, Mother Ildegarde Cabitza, as well as by priests, preachers, and visitors. Numerous sworn testimonies were collected, and medical analyses were performed on the blood. Cloths and purificators soaked with blood were preserved in the monastery archives. The Holy Office sent Father Luigi Romoli, O.P., as Apostolic Visitator to conduct a formal investigation, personally interrogating the nuns and imposing strict secrecy. On November 14, 1950, the Holy Office ordered the statue removed and kept in a secret location. It was returned to Rosano in 1952. Bishop Giovanni Giorgis interpreted the events as a call to fidelity, reparation, and prayer, while Bishop Luciano Giovannetti later encouraged renewed devotion to the Sacred Heart. The community lived these extraordinary events with discretion, continuing their monastic life according to the Benedictine motto 'Ora et Labora.'
scientificEvidence: Medical analyses of the blood were conducted; sworn eyewitness testimonies and ecclesiastical investigations, including a Holy Office inquiry, excluded natural explanations.
significance: The events renewed devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus and were interpreted by Church authorities as a call to prayer, conversion, and fidelity within the Diocese.

name: Eucharistic Miracle Witnessed by St. Peter Damian

location.address: Hermitage of Fonte Avellana, Italy

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host partially transformed into Flesh)
description: A consecrated Host stolen for sorcery was found transformed, half into visible Flesh and half retaining the appearance of bread.
narrative: Around the year 1050 in Italy, a woman, yielding to a grave temptation, attempted to steal a consecrated Host during Holy Communion in order to use it for sorcery at the request of a sorceress. She hid the Host in a white linen cloth. The priest noticed the act and pursued her, demanding that she reveal what she was hiding. When the cloth was unfolded, the stolen Host was found miraculously transformed: one half had become visibly the Flesh of Christ, while the other half retained the normal appearance of a Host. This extraordinary event was directly witnessed and later described by St. Peter Damian, Doctor of the Church, in his work *Opusculum XXXIV*. He explained that God permitted this miracle to convince unbelievers and heretics of the truth of the Real Presence, visibly demonstrating in one Host both the sacramental appearance and the true Body of Christ, thereby affirming the reality of transubstantiation at the moment of consecration.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is documented through the direct eyewitness testimony of St. Peter Damian, preserved in his theological writings and accepted within ecclesiastical tradition.
significance: This miracle served as a powerful theological affirmation of transubstantiation and was cited by a Doctor of the Church as evidence against disbelief in the Eucharistic mystery.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Salzano

location.address: Church of Saint Bartholomew, Salzano (Veneto)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Adoration of the Eucharist by animals)
description: Donkeys knelt, followed, and repeatedly genuflected before the Blessed Sacrament carried as Viaticum to a dying man.
narrative: In 1517, a priest named Father Lorenzo was urgently summoned to bring the Holy Viaticum to a dying parishioner on the western outskirts of Salzano. Because of the season and hour, no formal procession was possible, and the priest set out accompanied only by one altar boy. Upon reaching the meadows near the Muson River, several donkeys that were grazing suddenly turned toward the priest carrying the Blessed Sacrament. Approaching reverently, they knelt, then followed the Most Holy Sacrament all the way to the home of the infirm, repeatedly genuflecting along the route. After the Viaticum was administered, the donkeys accompanied Father Lorenzo back toward the fields, once again kneeling before returning to pasture. The event was widely transmitted through local oral tradition and later recorded by the Jesuit Servant of God Simone Rodriguez, whose account was examined by Church authorities. Saint Ignatius of Loyola and his companions learned of the miracle while staying in nearby cities in 1536. The episode was later cited by the Bollandists, ecclesiastical historians, and in official Jesuit histories. A fresco depicting the miracle is preserved in the Church of Saint Bartholomew, and documents, relics, and artworks are conserved in the Museum of Saint Pius X in Salzano.
scientificEvidence: Multiple independent historical testimonies, ecclesiastical examinations of contemporary records, and enduring documentary preservation support the authenticity of the event.
significance: The miracle reinforced belief in the Real Presence and became a lasting public witness to Eucharistic reverence, remembered in art, tradition, and ecclesial history.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Siena

location.address: Basilica of San Francesco, Siena (Tuscany)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Incorrupt consecrated Hosts)
description: Hundreds of consecrated Hosts stolen from a church were later recovered and have remained perfectly intact for centuries.
narrative: On the night of August 14, 1730, thieves broke into the Basilica of San Francesco in Siena and stole a ciborium containing 351 consecrated Hosts. Three days later, on August 17, the Hosts were found intact in the dust of the alms box at the Sanctuary of Santa Maria in Provenzano. The entire population of Siena celebrated their recovery, and the Hosts were solemnly returned in procession to the Basilica of San Francesco. Over the passing centuries, the Hosts showed no signs of decay or corruption, remaining fresh, intact, and chemically pure despite being composed of unleavened bread. Archbishop Tiberio Borghese sealed unconsecrated hosts in a tin box for ten years as a control experiment; when opened, only worms and rotted fragments were found. Numerous scientific examinations were conducted, including a major investigation authorized by Pope St. Pius X in 1914 involving professors of health, chemistry, and pharmacology. Additional tests followed in 1922, 1950, and 1951, all concluding that the preservation of the Hosts defied physical and biological laws. Pope John Paul II, during a visit to Siena on September 14, 1980, affirmed before the relics: “It is the Real Presence!” The sacred Hosts are displayed seasonally in the Chapel Piccolomini and the Chapel Martinozzi, and Siena continues to honor the miracle through monthly Eucharistic adoration, Corpus Christi processions, and civic tributes.
scientificEvidence: Multiple scientific commissions (1914, 1922, 1950–1951) confirmed the Hosts remain uncorrupted and chemically unchanged, contradicting natural laws of organic matter preservation.
significance: The miracle of Siena is one of the longest-lasting Eucharistic miracles in history and provides a sustained witness to the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Trani

location.address: Cathedral of Holy Mary of the Assumption; St. Andrew’s Church; Chapel at the former house of the woman, Trani (Puglia)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Host transformed into Flesh and Blood)
description: A consecrated Host placed into boiling oil poured forth abundant Blood that flowed through the house and into the street.
narrative: In the eleventh century in Trani, a non-Christian woman, incredulous about the Catholic doctrine of the Real Presence and aided by some Christian friends, managed to steal a consecrated Host during Holy Mass. As if daring God, she took the Host home and placed it into a frying pan filled with boiling oil to test whether it was truly bread. Upon contact with the oil, the consecrated Host was transformed into bloody Flesh, and an extraordinary hemorrhage ensued, with Blood pouring from the pan, spreading over the woman and throughout the house, and flowing out into the street. Terrified, the woman began to scream, drawing neighbors who quickly informed ecclesiastical authorities. The Archbishop ordered the immediate return of the Host to the church. The event was recorded by Brother Bartolomeo Campi in his 1625 work “L’Inamorato di Gesù Cristo” and later noted by the Cistercian Abbot Ferdinando Ughelli in “Italia Sacra” (1670). Over the centuries, the relic was transferred to a silver shrine, the house of the woman was converted into a chapel in 1706, and numerous verifications were conducted, the most recent in 1924 during the Inter-diocesan Eucharistic Congress led by Monsignor Giuseppe Maria Leo. The relics of the miracle are preserved in Trani, and the city bears ancient Eucharistic monograms marking remembrance of the prodigy.
scientificEvidence: Historical documentation, episcopal intervention, preserved relics, repeated ecclesiastical verifications, and later formal examinations (including in 1924) support the authenticity of the event.
significance: The miracle of Trani stands as a dramatic medieval witness to the Real Presence and remains a defining element of the city’s Eucharistic devotion.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Turin

location.address: Basilica of Corpus Domini, Piazza Corpus Domini, Turin (Piedmont)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Levitation and descent of the Sacred Host)
description: A stolen consecrated Host rose miraculously into the air and later descended into a chalice before the Bishop and the people of Turin.
narrative: On June 6, 1453, during military conflict in the Alta Val di Susa near Exilles, soldiers plundered a church and stole a monstrance containing a consecrated Host. One soldier placed the stolen Host into a bag and set off toward Turin on a she-mule. Upon reaching the main square near the Church of Saint Sylvester (now the Church of the Holy Spirit), the mule suddenly stumbled and fell. At that moment, the bag opened and the monstrance containing the consecrated Host rose high into the air above the surrounding houses, filling the crowd with awe. News quickly reached Bishop Ludovico of Romagnano, who came in procession with clergy and faithful. Kneeling in adoration, he prayed the words of the disciples of Emmaus: “Stay with us, Lord.” Then a second prodigy occurred: the monstrance fell, releasing the Host, which shone brilliantly like a second sun. Holding a chalice, the Bishop raised it, and the consecrated Host slowly descended and rested inside it. The miracle was immediately documented and officially recognized in the Capitulary Acts of 1454, 1455, and 1456. Devotion spread rapidly, leading first to the construction of an aedicule on the site and later to the Basilica of Corpus Domini. The miracle has been commemorated through major centennial celebrations, papal acts—including approval of a proper Mass by Pope Pius IX—and continuous public devotion. The physical place of the miracle is still marked inside the basilica by an iron railing and inscriptions.
scientificEvidence: The miracle is supported by contemporaneous municipal records, three Capitulary Acts (1454–1456), eyewitness testimony, episcopal documentation, and centuries of uninterrupted public veneration.
significance: The miracle of Turin is one of the most documented Eucharistic miracles in history and became a defining spiritual event for the city, profoundly strengthening faith in the Real Presence.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Turin (Santa Maria del Monte)

location.address: Church of Santa Maria del Monte (Capuchin Church of the Monte), Turin (Piedmont)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Fire emanating from the ciborium)
description: Flames burst from the ciborium when a soldier attempted to desecrate the consecrated Hosts, burning his face and leaving a permanent handprint on the tabernacle.
narrative: In May 1640, during the military invasion of Piedmont by the French army of Count Harcourt, foreign troops advanced toward Turin after crossing the River Po. On May 12, soldiers occupied the Capuchin Church of Santa Maria del Monte, where many civilians had taken refuge. While the Capuchin friars were spared, numerous men, women, and children were massacred inside the church, and sacred vessels and vestments were profaned. In the midst of this violence, a French soldier—an unbeliever—climbed onto the altar and forced open the tabernacle containing a ciborium with several consecrated Hosts, intending to desecrate them. Suddenly, flames of fire miraculously burst forth from the ciborium and enveloped the soldier, scorching his face and burning his clothing. Terrified, he threw himself to the ground screaming and begging God’s forgiveness. Dense smoke filled the church, and the sacrilegious violence immediately ceased. The tabernacle door, adorned with agate and lapis lazuli, still bears the visible imprint of the soldier’s burned hand. The event was described in detail by Capuchin friar Pier Maria da Cambiano and commemorated in paintings and records preserved in the church, where the miracle remains a lasting testimony to the Real Presence.
scientificEvidence: Eyewitness testimony recorded by Capuchin friars, the preserved physical evidence of the scorched handprint on the tabernacle door, and continuous historical documentation support the event.
significance: The miracle powerfully affirmed the sanctity of the Eucharist during a time of war and sacrilege and remains a visible sign of Eucharistic reverence in Turin.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Veroli

location.address: Church of St. Erasmus, Veroli (Lazio)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Apparition of the Child Jesus in the Host)
description: During Eucharistic adoration, the Child Jesus appeared in the exposed Host, accompanied by a radiant star and angelic figures.
narrative: During Easter of 1570, in the Church of St. Erasmus in Veroli, the Blessed Sacrament was solemnly exposed for the Forty Hours devotion according to the liturgical custom of the time. The consecrated Host was first placed in a round silver pyx, then enclosed in a burse-like holder, and finally set within a large ceremonial chalice covered by a paten and wrapped in an elegant silk cloth. During one of the hours of adoration, attended by members of the Confraternity of Mercy dressed in black robes and kneeling in prayer, a miraculous apparition occurred. According to the sworn testimony of Giacomo Meloni, one of the first witnesses, a brilliant star appeared at the base of the chalice, above which the Blessed Sacrament was visible in the form of the Host used at Mass. Around the Host, small children resembling angels appeared in adoration. The event was immediately recorded by the ecclesiastical chancery, and the official document is preserved in the archives of the Church of St. Erasmus. The miraculous Host was preserved and consumed 112 years later. The chalice, paten, and silver pyx used for the exposition remain preserved among the church’s relics. The miracle has been commemorated ever since with solemn ceremonies in the presence of the bishop, and Eucharistic adoration continues regularly in Veroli, notably marked during the fourth centenary in 1970 with a diocesan Eucharistic Congress.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by sworn eyewitness testimony, immediate official ecclesiastical documentation preserved in the church archives, and the continued preservation of the sacred vessels involved.
significance: The miracle of Veroli strengthened Eucharistic devotion in the region and remains a lasting testimony to the Real Presence manifested through a visible apparition during public adoration.

name: Eucharistic Miracle of Volterra

location.address: Cathedral of Volterra; Church of Saint Francis (archives), Volterra (Tuscany)

type: Eucharistic Miracle (Levitation and luminous suspension of the Sacred Hosts)
description: Consecrated Hosts thrown against a church wall rose into the air, shining with a mysterious light and remaining suspended for a long time.
narrative: In 1472, during the violent conflict between Volterra and Florence that culminated in the sacking of the city, a Florentine soldier entered the Cathedral of Volterra and stole an ivory ciborium containing numerous consecrated Hosts. Driven by fury and hatred toward Jesus in the Eucharist, he hurled the ciborium with its sacred contents against an exterior wall of the church. Immediately, all the Hosts burst forth and—illuminated by a mysterious light—rose into the air and remained suspended for a long time, as if held by an invisible hand. Terrified by what he had done, the soldier fell to the ground, repented, and began to cry. Many witnesses were present at the event. Among the most authoritative accounts is the written relation of Friar Biagio Lisci, a direct eyewitness, whose testimony is preserved in the archives of the Church of Saint Francis. Additional municipal acts documenting the event are kept in the municipal library of Volterra. The miracle occurred within a broader historical context marked by social conflict, the interests of Lorenzo de’ Medici, and harsh reprisals against Volterra following its absorption into the Florentine state.
scientificEvidence: The event is supported by contemporaneous eyewitness testimony, written relations preserved in ecclesiastical archives, and municipal acts maintained in the city library of Volterra.
significance: The miracle of Volterra offered a striking public witness to the Real Presence during a time of war and sacrilege, reinforcing Eucharistic faith amid social and political turmoil.
